PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: Petition for closing the `Joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the oceans.
2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a `first strike' attack.
This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the `Joint Australian-U.S.' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that:

Without any warning and at the worst possible moment, the Federal Government has abandoned the pensioner patients in South Australia's Nursing Homes. These people are suffering undeserving hardship and trauma as a result of the Federal Government's decision to freeze the nursing home benefit levels in South Australia.

The pensioner patients and those on fixed incomes now cannot expect any relief from recent significant fee increases approved by the Department of Community Services and which have coincided with the decision to freeze benefits.

80-85 per cent of nursing home patients are pensioners and the majority are now required to pay in excess of their pension for their nursing care for the very first time. Some are paying over $5 per day on top of their pension. Many are looking for cheaper nursing care that doesn't exist.
We request that the Federal Government:

1. alleviate the distress of South Australia's nursing home patients and their families by effective restoration of the principle that pensioner patients should not have to pay more than their pension for nursing home care
2. restore the review of the benefit rates in November 1985
3. resolve its concerns over health care costs with the South Australian Government rather than inflicting unnecessary suffering on nursing home patients.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective menthod of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud:
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:-
The unrelenting ever expanding money extortion to which home purchasers are being subjected has exceeded the bounds of all logical reason. It is neither linear or progressive.

It becomes transparently clear that the constant edging up of interest rates for investors by banks, lending institutions, and banking consortiums are collectively responsible for the monetary explosion, lack of employment and all that that entails and is causing grave social disruption to hundreds of thousands. Behind it all, the absence of control that is now politically essential in the interest of justice and fair distribution of burden.
No government, recent or future should tolerate this cruel, vicious procedure that shatters the existence of family life, together with all the well known disastrous repercussions that follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge all politicians to unite nationally to do all within their power to reduce interest rates across the board and that:-

This country needs a five year period to reduce this unwarranted absurdity by tackling it at its source, as follows: firstly a 2 per cent annual interest reduction on home loans, until it is down to 6 per cent. This to come into force immediately subject to the urgent necessary legislation.

This would, or should curtail union demands, and cause no hazard for investors, who could reinvest in Government projects, or other worthwhile ventures. It would also certainly ease the burden on social securities.
Your petitioners as in duty bond will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Siddons) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to encourage the introduction of employee participation in Australian enterprises through reductions in company tax for enterprises classified as employee participation enterprises.
Bill presented by Senator Siddons, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

During the first week of this Budget session I introduced the Industrial Democracy Bill 1985. I called it my Industrial Democracy Bill, because it was similar in approach to an Industrial Democracy Bill I introduced into the Senate in 1980. I have since learned, however, that Industrial Democracy is the name being given by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, to initiatives within his Department which involve the trade unions in power sharing arrangements within industry and other features that will result in inevitable misrepresentations of my own Bill. It has therefore become essential to change the name of my Bill to the Employee Participation Bill. This name reflects the changes that were recently incorporated into the Bill and better describes the essential thrust of the Bill.

My Bill is not concerned with power sharing-in fact the reverse is the case. It is concerned with restoring a measure of power to the individual. It is concerned with creating an environment in the eight hour working day that allows the individual greater opportunity to use his or her abilities, expertise, initiative and to contribute ideas for the general improvement of the organisations in which they work. I neither criticise nor endorse Mr Willis's work under his industrial democracy banner. I will wait until I see the legislation before commenting. But I stress that the worker participation I advocate requires a co-operative, voluntary enviroment to be created in the workplace free of duress. One can encourage people to co-operate and contribute. One cannot force them to do so. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the remainder of my second reading speech.
Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows-

What is the secret of the Japanese success? They have a different approach to the management of their companies. They have embraced wholeheartedly for many years now the principle of employee participation. They have developed organisational structures that provide for the total involvement of all employees, and an ability to take notice of the individual.

As a practising industrialist, and one who has led for some 30 years an industry that has achieved considerable success in improving the principles of employee participation, I now introduce this re-structured Bill which takes account of continuing and up-to-the-minute experience in this area.

Employee participation has long been at the very base of a number of the world's modern industrial economies. The two most spectacular examples are Sweden and Japan. After the war, starting from a pile of rubble, the Japanese commenced the task of building an industrial machine that has become the envy of the world. Employee participation was the driving force which allowed this mammoth feat to be achieved. Worker participation has produced in Japan a totally different relationship between managent and workers in stark contrast to what we find here in Australia. As any business men or women who have been to Japan will testify, the co-operation at every level of the Japanese industrial complex make them a formidable commercial opponent.

They lead the world in almost every aspect of industrial endeavour to which they have turned their attention. Now they dominate world production of cars, motor cycles, machine tools and watches, and are challenging for world leadership in computers, typewriters, videos, sewing machines, industrial robots, micro-processors and so on. The list is endless.

I can say from practical experience that these principles work. I have seen them work in my own and other industries in Australia, and I have seen them work in Japan. Do we want our industries to be internationally competitive? This can be achieved only through co-operation between worker and management. The Government has a responsibility to encourage this to happen.

The Bill contains five criteria which define what is meant by employee participation. An enterprise that can convince a seven-member employee participation board that it has substantially complied with at least four of the five criteria will be eligible to apply for a Government incentive in the form of an 8 per cent reduction in Company tax.
The five criteria are:
(1) At least 8 per cent employee share holding to give employees a stake in the enterprise in which they work.

(2) A cellular organisation with autonomous working groups based on performance centres throughout the enterprise. This is important because such groups have the ability to meet change quickly, and to engender innovation.
(3) A profit sharing scheme to reward people for their efforts and to ensure open communication on such things as sales performance and profits.
(4) A consultative council to discuss small internal problems before they become major matters requiring the attention of trade unions, and

(5) Small group activity. This is a very important provision of the Bill and requires that an enterprise establish small groups of about 10 people throughout the entire organisation. These groups are to be led by carefully selected and trained group leaders and are required to discuss, during working hours, such things as quality, efficiency, innovation and new equipment and to make recommendations on these to management.

The question may well be asked-if employee participation is so good for business, then why does it not adopt it anyway, without government assistance? The first answer is that most Australians, including Australian executives, have only a very hazy idea about what is meant by employee participation. It means different things to different people, and like motherhood is generally perceived to be a good thing. Australians have talked about employee participation for many years, but very few companies have applied even its rudimentary principles. This is because there is an ingrained conservatism in Australian management along the lines that workers are there to do what they are told, and amongst workers that they are not employed to tell the boss how to do his job. It needs a Government initiative to break down these ingraned attitudes in Australia. Once the change of attitude gets under way, and people see that companies applying the principles set out in this Bill are successful, and once the Employee Participation Board starts disseminating through our tertiary institutions information on how to successfully apply the principles, then employee participation in Australia will become self-perpetuating and the Government, if it wishes could progressively withdraw from the scene.

This Bill requires the Government to make $20m available each year for the first five years, and then to reassess the situation. If it is to overcome its critical balance of trade problem, it must turn to the manufacturing sector to improve its export performance. Our industries can be, and should be, as efficient as any in the world. If the Government co-operates, we can do it.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:

DEBATE.TITLE: NORTHERN PRAWN FISHERY VOLUNTARY ADJUSTMENT SCHEME LOAN GUARANTEE BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--
—Do you identify yourself as a northern prawn?

—Not by any standards. Last night before the adjournment debate we were discussing three fishing Bills cognately. The $5m self-help program which the fishing industry asked for has been granted under this legislation and, of course, the industry is very thankful for that. The main problem, as I was telling the Senate last night, is that 38 per cent of this $5m is to go towards administration costs. This is causing the industry a lot of concern.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry wants to be able to run its own organisation as do most other rural industries in Australia. The Australian Wheat Board, the Australian Wool Corporation and all the other rural industry boards manage their own affairs and the fishing industry wants to do so also. It believes that the best people to run their own organisations know the problems of their industry and know how to solve those problems are the fishermen themselves. I believe that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is moving towards that objective by organising an advisory policy council of fishermen which will advise him on the needs of the fishing industry. I hope that we will then be only a step away from organising a council to run the industry. I believe that it will be coalition policy on return to government to give the industry its own operation, its own organisation, with statutory powers to control its own affairs.

The industry is very happy with the negotiations entered into by the Department of Primary Industry on the Japanese long line operations. Of course, that has resulted in a reduction of tonnage quotas and the area where foreign boats can work is now restricted. At the same time the fishing industry is concerned about the Thai joint venture being conducted out of Darwin. The industry recognises that the Thai joint venture has to compete in the international market place and find markets for the Australian product. Most of the other fishing industries in the world-probably all of them-get some government assistance, but the Australian fishing industry, being made up of rugged individuals, is prepared to stand on its own feet. Those in the industry are prepared to contribute support levies such as those in these Bills, but it should be noted by the Minister that every other fishing industry gets some help by way of subsidised fuel and subsidised wharfage. All the great fishing industries in the world, including the Japanese fishing fleet, get government assistance, which has not been forthcoming from this Government.

I support the Bills. They are what the fishing industry has been wanting for the last 10 years. I think that the Government could have been a little more generous with terms of interest in view of the fact that it is receiving $40m from the excise on fuel that the fishing industry needs. I think that to make the fishing industry go to commercial rates of interest is unreasonable. There should be a subsidised rate of interest. However, as I said before, the fishermen wanted the legislation. They are prepared to accept it and stand on their own feet. I support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honour- able senators for their support of these pieces of legislation. In particular I thank Senator Boswell. It is not often that we hear Senator Boswell praise the Government. I know that he had to reach out for something to hit us over the head with at one stage. I think it is interesting that, as a member of the National Party, he should pick that particular thing to hit us over the head with. As Senator Boswell said, the prawn fishermen involved in this legislation are independent people and free enterprise people; they want to be free enterprise people. Senator Boswell says: `You know, what you really should have done is given them a subsidy'.
—That is called agrarian socialism.
—That is called agrarian socialism. What Senator Boswell and his colleagues are about is that they come here and say-
—I don't know why I ever try to be nice to you people. I'm going in boots and all from now on.

—I am speaking in a whimsical sort of way. They come in here and say: `We believe in free enterprise and in keeping the Government out'. Here we have a situation where the fishermen say: `We want a plan, we want to buy our plan and we want to run our own industry and the Government says we can do so'. Senator Boswell agrees with that. I must admit that it makes a great change from the sort of nonsense he talks about the sugar industry, which is also supposed to comprise free enterprise people and into which he wants big buckets of money poured, and about every other rural industry he represents. But I thank him for his praise. I understand the difficulties he has in completely praising us at all times. I suppose we have to be thankful for small mercies.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines, in a very thoughtful contribution to this debate-it is early in the morning; that is why I am in such a pleasant mood-asked a couple of questions about the problems which were raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's Alert Digest about this legislation. I will promptly regurgitate for her the notes I have been given on the subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a nice note the people on the other side of the barrier have written for you.

—She asked basically two things. She asked, as did the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, whether parliamentary scrutiny is without the power to disallow the most appropriate method for reviewing a decision of the Minister that levy is not payable in respect of a licensed foreign boat operated under Australian management. What happens is we get bits of paper which say `suggested response'. My advice is that the purpose of the proposed new sub-section 4 (4) is to permit the Government to exempt the licensed foreign boat from levy payment without the need to enter into the type of agreement mentioned in section 9C of the Fisheries Act 1952 and then using the power in that section to exempt the boat from levy. That is the way we go about it. The Government has approved exemptions from levy only in cases such as those mentioned in the second reading speech-for instance, where no suitable Australian boat is available to undertake the operation. There must be some benefit to Australia before we waive the levy under section 9C of the Fisheries Act and the foreign boats must be under Australian management.
—But nobody knows what it is.

—Even I can understand this. Section 16A provides for a review of certain decisions made under the Act. A decision under section 9C-for instance, to waive levy-is not included in the reviewable decisions. A decision to review a licence is subject to review. If the licence is granted, there would be no reason to waive the levy. If the licence is refused, the question of waiving the levy does not arise. It is all logical. It is all quite clear.
—To somebody, it probably is.

—Senator Haines also asked, as the Scrutiny of Bills Committee did, whether it was appropriate for the Parliament to delegate to the Minister the power to set the amount of the foreign fishing boat levy in certain cases, thus, it could be said, delegating its taxing powers without retaining control over how those powers are exercised. That is certainly a question worth raising.
—What is the suggested response?

—The suggested response is that the relevant agreement between the Minister and the foreign interests concerned is in fact tabled in the Parliament. The amount of the access fee is specified. The present Act imposes a prescribed amount of levy on every licence. The number of boats that eventually apply for licences may be different from that envisaged in the agreement. The amendment proposes that the agreed amount of the levy be paid regardless of the number of boats. Parliament has the power to disallow a provision of any regulation under the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Act 1984 prescribing the amount of levy payable, but a dis- allowance of this type prescribing the amount of levy payable would give rise to difficulties in giving effect to the agreement. Since 1979 the Government has entered into an agreement as an exercise of its executive authority. It advises the Parliament of its action and the agreement provides the legal authority for the collection of access fees. This, it is asserted, is a satisfactory basis for exercising the power of the Executive in respect of off-shore sovereignty and sovereign rights for entering into contractual agreements and collecting revenue.
—But we still cannot do anything about it if we do not like it.

—Yes, the Parliament can. The Parliament can disallow a provision of any of those regulations but not the agreement itself. Senator Haines can come in here and hit us over the head, disallow all the regulations and the agreement is worthless.
—That is the traditional nut and sledgehammer approach.
—It may be traditional. I realise that Senator Haines and I do not necessarily take much of a view of tradition, but that is the way things are done and have been done.
—That makes it all right.

—That probably makes it all right. It does not seem to worry our colleagues opposite. As I said earlier, I thank honourable senators for their support for these important pieces of legislation. The fishing industry is being developed with the co-operation of the fishermen themselves, as Senator Boswell said. I am glad it is continuing to be developed in co-operation with both sides of this Parliament.
