SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1985 is a normal machinery measure to establish funding for the States for welfare housing and other works programs in the States. The Opposition's concerns are chiefly with the economic direction of this Government. Many of the decisions which lie behind these funding Bills for the States are critical to the understanding of the decisions which the Government has undertaken recently in this area. Perhaps I should start by sketching a little of the economic scenario in which the Government has sought to undertake these various programs. I draw the Senate's attention to the very high level of interest rates in this country at present which dramatically affect the level of activity in both housing and public works right across the country. Not only is the public sector of the construction industry affected but also, naturally enough, private investment is.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us turn to interest rates and their effect on the average wage earner. This Bill sets aside a large part of its funds for the development of welfare housing in the States. It is becoming increasingly apparent that there will be greater and greater demands upon that sector as a result of this Government's policies. I mentioned earlier the high interest rates that exist in this country at present. It is absolutely clear that under the Hawke Labor Government this country has the highest real interest rates in its history. In fact, since this Government came to power in March 1983 we have had a continuous growth in real interest rates from about 2 or 3 per cent to a rate these days of about 8 per cent. We are talking about real interest rates, that is, the difference between the nominal rate, which people are charged when they take out loans on their homes, less an allowance for the current rate of inflation. Real interest rates are the major determining factor or indicator when people are deciding to invest in long term projects. That factor is now at its highest level in this nation's history-all brought about by the direct policies of the Hawke Labor Government.

Obviously, real interest rates are a critical factor in understanding the background to which this legislation seeks to draw the nation's attention. The present real interest rates are clearly detrimental to the potential of the development of both housing and private investment and, therefore, job creation across the nation. The effect of these interest rates is being felt at all levels of the community. I draw the attention of the Senate especially to the recent action of the South Australian Government under Premier John Bannon, who is facing an election very soon. He realises the political heat of the market-place. Voters in the outer suburban areas of Adelaide find that their mortgages are going through the roof, that they are having to meet more of their repayments from their own pockets; or, if that is not happening, they find that the loans which they took out, say, on a 20-year basis, are being adjusted to a 29-year or 30-year basis. So they are getting behind year after year.

Mr Bannon, because he is under a certain degree of political pressure now with an election around the corner, has decided to subsidise the building societies to the tune of $3m a year from the State Government's Treasury in order to keep down interest rates. One might think that is an admirable course to follow but when one considers what it will do to the rest of the money markets and, in particular, the banks, credit unions and other financial institutions in South Australia, one can see that there will be a widespread ripple effect, or, if you like, a kind of vacuum cleaner, into which the State Government ultimately will be totally drawn if it does not face the reality of the market-place in terms of interest rates. It is clear that the Premier of South Australia has only one view in mind and that is winning the next State election. Therefore, anything he might do to spend taxpayers' money in whatever way, irresponsible or otherwise, is all fair game when votes are at stake. The Bannon Labor Government of South Australia is clearly oriented in that way, determined to stay alive after the next State election, which aim is not likely to be achieved.

The interest rate factor is building up as a major issue, not only in terms of elections but also in terms of the day to day existence of individuals right across Australia. We have to realise that all this is happening at a time when there is a great deal of pressure on people's pockets in other regards. For instance, the average wage earner is now being hit by increased inflation as a result of this Government's policies. Inflation is rising in each quarter. It has been announced in the last year that the annual rate of inflation is probably of the order of 8 per cent and many respectable economic commentators are now predicting a 10 per cent rate of inflation for the year ended 30 June 1986. That being so-one has only to listen to pensioners to know that food costs at the supermarket are rising day by day at a far greater rate than are their indexed pensions-the effects are also being felt in the household pockets. So, at a time when increased mortgage payments are going to hurt people, a higher cost of living results from ordinary rises in food costs and other living costs. Consequently, people are going to feel the heat very significantly in the year ahead under this Government's policies.

The tax package which has been brought down in recent times also has a very important bearing on this area. I instance the effect of the Government's decision to disallow deductions under the negative gearing arrangements. This, combined with the capital gains tax, has had and will have a very significant effect upon the ability of private investors to develop properties, houses, units and other commercial buildings for low income earners. Clearly, it will restrict the ability of people to entertain economic decisions pertaining to those kinds of developments. As a result, a shortage of houses for low and middle income earners will occur in the months and years ahead and we can expect rents payable by those people to rise very significantly.

In this country about half a million people receive supplementary rental assistance through social security. If rents rise, say, by $5 a week on average across the community, people who are on pensions and benefits find themselves unable to meet the repayment of that extra $5 and the Government decides that supplementary assistance ought to be made available in order to cover it, that is an extra cost to the Government of $2 1/2m a week. On an annual basis that is something like $130m. That comes as a result of increasing rents by $5 a week. The Government will deliberately contribute to that increase in rent by introducing the capital gains tax and by disallowing expenses under negative gearing arrangements. Yet, the total revenue that the Government will get next year from abolishing negative gearing is a mere $55m; so if the Government is forced to bail out pensioners to the tune of $130m it will be faced with a loss in terms of the revenue it gets from abolishing negative gearing. Of course, capital gains tax will not come into force or produce any revenue until 1990. We do not want capital gains tax at all, but that just shows how confused this Government is, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I know you feel that way as well, judging by the odd occasion on which you have spoken publicly on various aspects of the Government's tax package.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better tell us how the fringe benefits tax will hurt the poor.

—I do not think that that is relevant to this debate on works and housing, and I think that the Acting Deputy President agrees with me on that matter. The point is made. This Government is confused about its tax package, it has no sense of direction and perhaps the Minister could explain to us how he can reconcile the introduction of a capital gains tax in order to take account of people who are otherwise negatively gearing properties, with the abolition, at the same time, of negative gearing for tax purposes. The two actions are contradictory and the justification that the Minister has been making for a long time about abolishing negative gearing deductions is now taken care of by the introduction of this so-called capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The capital gains tax is nothing more nor less than a device to make the rich richer and the poor poorer. Those who had assets prior to 19 September 1985 will not have to pay any capital gains tax, whereas those who are trying to acquire assets after 19 September 1985 will have to pay the tax. Consequently they will lose the benefit of being able to accumulate assets at the same rate as people who already have them. Therefore, the result will be absolutely the opposite to the one that the Government expects. The gulf between the rich and the poor in Australia will be even greater, all because of the Government's misguided, contradictory and confused policies on taxation which roll over into the whole area of financial affairs and policy in this country.

Having demolished the Government's policies on taxation and having shown up the very significant weaknesses in its direction, I reiterate the major point of this argument: This Government is presiding over the highest real interest rates in this country's history. These have been induced deliberately as a central part of the Government's economic policy. The reason is simple. The Government has got this country into such a mess because of its lack of competitiveness overseas that our dollar is collapsing in terms of prices on world markets. The dollar has to be devalued of course in order to try to offset the huge wage increases that we have suffered over recent times, which make us uncompetitive on world markets. Therefore, in order to offset the problems of bringing in enough money to cover our huge deficit overseas-now standing at about $11 billion a year-the Government must, as a fundamental instrument of its tax and economic policies, keep interest rates high. It must do that in order to attract capital from overseas to balance the budget. That is the simple fact of life that this Government is living with. Therefore, interest rates must stay high while the Government flounders around dealing with its wages policy. At the same time it fails to impress anybody in the community that it has a firm hand on the economic tiller. That is exactly the circumstance we are facing in this country now as a result of the Hawke Labor Government's policies.

In respect of the States, the heat will be felt increasingly by State governments and other bodies which are spending in the areas of capital works and housing developments. That will come two ways-first, through the increased cost of money to those States as a result of high interest rates that they are now suffering and, secondly, through rising inflation in the cost of the development of their projects and of the buildings, materials and labour costs associated with those projects. As a result, we can expect to see more and more State Premiers queueing up at the door of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer at the Premiers Conference in June 1986. They will be looking for more money to meet the project commitments they are now entering into. The obvious cause of those problems lies squarely at the feet of this Government because of its economic mismanagement and its failure to keep interest rates on a downward path.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Messner has already indicated, the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1985 is a machinery Bill which has been introduced to legislate Loan Council agreements. First, it gives $558m in free capital grants to the States and, secondly, it provides concessional loans at low interest rates to the States and Territories for public housing in 1985-86. This legislation arises out of a decision taken at the Loan Council meeting in May this year and authorises payments resulting from those decisions which fall outside the provisions of the Financial Agreement Act 1928. The Bill specifically seeks to authorise a number of things, including the payment of general purpose capital grants to the States in the last half of this year and the first half of next year, the pre-payment of capital grants during the first six months of 1986-87, pending passage of similar legislation in that year, and the continued payment in the next three years of loans on concessional terms and conditions of amounts nominated by the States and the Northern Territory from their approved borrowing programs. It also provides scope for the payment of concessional housing loans in the first six months of the next three years, the amount to be advanced to each State under this provision being limited to an amount equal to half the amount it was permitted to nominate in the previous year.

SPEECH.PARA: The grants were originally introduced to help the States finance works such as schools and other capital works from which debt charges are not normally recovered. In this legislation the Government has, as the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) said in his second reading speech, recognised the considerable contribution made, by arrangement, to the financing of public housing in the States by way of the encouragement it has given to the States to increase their housing expenditure. This is something devoutly to be wished because the public housing sector certainly needs a boost and is likely to need a bigger boost in the future, partly for some of the reasons Senator Messner suggested and partly for others. In the past governments in Australia have tended to concentrate their subsidies on the private ownership sector. For example, in 1977 subsidies to private home ownership were in the vicinity of $811 per capita, while the subsidy to the public housing sector was $769 per capita and the subsidy in the rental housing sector was a mere $190 per capita. By 1983 a $1,500 per capita subsidy was paid to home ownership-the 1977 figure almost doubled-while the public housing subsidy figure of $400 per capita was the reverse-that is, almost half the subsidy offered in 1977. The subsidy to the rental housing sector in 1983 was $170 per capita, which was marginally lower than that which applied in 1977. Those sorts of figures are cause for concern amongst a number of people in the community. There has been an increasing number of newspaper reports, television programs and so on about problems in the housing industry and about problems that individuals and families have in acquiring a roof over their heads. We have all heard stories about the number of people who live in caravans around Australia and the number of young people who are living in cars, bus shelters and so on. These problems are not going to go away while the Government merely concentrates its attention on subsidising private house ownership.

Certainly I accept that the Federal Government this year announced that it would do something to help people out of poverty traps involving lack of access to housing. But as I understand it, the increase in the availability of rental assistance, for example, will not come into effect until November of next year, which leaves us with a quite long period in which people can still find themselves in difficulties.

Senator Messner raised the spectre of problems that are likely to be caused by the introduction of measures in respect of negative gearing and capital gains taxes. I must say that I-like, I suspect, a number of senators in the chamber at the time-got a little confused about his argument. He seemed to be attacking the Government for not making the capital gains tax retrospective when I would have thought he would at least have been applauding that. There are arguments in the community about just what the effect of negative gearing measures and new capital gains tax provisions is likely to be. A report in the Age of 28 August this year quoted a sociologist who argued that the changes to the tax system would not be the cause, or the only cause, of a rent crisis that he sees as coming fairly soon. On 27 August one Terry Burke, senior lecturer in sociology at the Swinburne Institute of Technology, disputed claims that tax changes affecting investment would cause a crisis in the private rental housing market in Australia. He said that there was already a rental housing crisis and that it had been caused by a growing demand from low income people-not by land- lords getting out of the rental business. I suggest that a large part of that demand from low income people has been due to government policies in the past, including such things as first home owners schemes, which are pitched not at low income earners but at middle income earners so that the problem focuses almost entirely on those people who are already facing financial crises of one sort or another.

Senator Messner also mentioned the problem likely to be caused to individuals and families by possible deregulation of housing loan interest rates, and certainly by the current pressure for the 13 1/2 per cent ceiling to be raised. As has been pointed out in this place in recent weeks, banks are already getting around that ceiling by introducing service fees of one sort or another. These really are only a ceiling lift by some other name.

I must say that Senator Messner commented on these things with some gall, since I recall that the last years of the Fraser Government were notorious for the continual increases in interest rates from home loans. I remember in those years the increasing number of people who were facing mortgagee sales because they were simply not in a position to budget continually for an increased outlay to the bank. To extend the term of a loan, of course, is a fairly temporary solution for most people. The term can be extended to only a certain extent and when this limit is reached they face the problem again of having to find, out of the housekeeping, an extra $10, $20 or $30 a month to pay the additional interest burden.

I recall saying on several occasions in the Senate during those years that this was having dramatic and somewhat deleterious effect in other sectors in the community. When housing loan interest rates rise, when one's mortgage repayment goes up each month and there is no commensurate increase in the pay packet, obviously decisions have to be made about how expenditure within the family budget is to be altered. The first thing to go is usually the standard of food that the family consumes. This inevitably has an effect on the small business people in the area-the local butcher, greengrocers and so on. That of course in turn spreads out into the community. Clothing is something that people look at twice before expending money if money is tight. Families with children are particularly hard hit since the little wretches have a tendency to grow out of things at an amazing rate if they are anything like my two. It is not an easy thing for a parent to say to a child: `I am sorry but you have to wear that particular pair of shoes or jeans or your school uniform or whatever for another couple of months because we simply cannot afford the $20 or $30 required to replace them'. It is certainly not easy on the child either, so all sorts of internal family problems arise as a consequence.

It is not just those areas, however, that are affected. Purchases of major items-a new car, a replacement for the washing machine that is internally haemorrhaging, a replacement for the refrigerator that has developed a terminal illness-are all put off if the demands of higher interest rate payments are forced down the throats of families. When they are finally forced out of their home, or when they are placed in a position where they cannot afford to take out a loan in the first place in order to buy privately, there is obviously a commensurate increase in the pressure placed on both the private rental market and on the demand for public housing. If the statistics that I have cited are correct, neither of these things is being attended to by governments nor has been in the past. I suspect that we will regret that if we do not pay attention to it fairly soon.

On the question of negative gearing and the capital gains tax, I would have thought that any fair-minded person in the community would argue that we ought to have in this country an equitable, fair, relatively uncomplicated and loophole-free tax system. To allow some people to pay virtually no tax because they can get involved in negative gearing programs, to allow others to make large profits of a capital nature from the sale of property and one thing and another and not pay tax on these profits, is grossly inequitable when the average worker has no say about how much tax he or she contributes to Consolidated Revenue. Rather than complain about proposals which attempt to end negative gearing and which attempt to make the tax system more equitable by taxing capital gains, we ought to be looking at some way of re-routing the income that governments recieve from the new tax measures into the housing sector. If, as some people argue, the introduction of stops on negative gearing programs and the introduction of a capital gains tax will in fact cause people not to purchase flats and houses and so on for rental purposes, the Government ought to be injecting large amounts of money into areas that will provide the roofs over people's heads that apparently will be missing from the private sector. That means that we will have to inject large amounts of funds into the provision of public housing and rental assistance subsidies.

We need to have a close look at the Australian dream of owning one's own home. Something like 70 per cent of people in Australia own their own homes. The other 30 per cent may, for all I know, aspire to it. That ownership figure is certainly higher than that in almost any other country in the world. We need to do the sorts of things that the South Australian Housing Trust is doing. From my movements around the States, looking at various housing commissions and housing trusts, I have to say, with absolutely no parochialism whatsoever, that the South Australian Housing Trust is one of the most forward-looking public housing authorities in Australia. It is not by any means perfect. At the moment it is engaged in a program of shipping people on low incomes and in poverty situations out of the city into country areas. This places a tremendous burden on country towns in the Riverland, in the south-east and in the Iron Triangle of South Australia, because those low income people are not in a position to contribute a great deal to the economics of an area but they place instead an increased burden on the services in that area. The services in country towns in South Australia are no different from services in country areas in any other State in that they are somewhat depleted. These moves also place a burden on the people concerned because adults and children are being moved away from the environment that they are familiar with and away from friends and families whom they could use for support.

On the other hand, having made that criticism of the Housing Trust's programs, I have to say that it also attempts to integrate its public housing into the general community. It tries to avoid establishing ghettos and instead it purchases older homes and builds new ones in areas where private ownership and private rental also exist. In some council areas the Trust is also looking at other sorts of flexible programs for housing people of all ages and all types so that there is some mobility in housing for young couples, families with large numbers of children, older people and so on.

I know that a few years ago one local government body in a country area in South Australia was looking at organising its housing so that when young couples needed a home they would have available to them a stock of fairly small homes, units and flats that would be adequate for their needs. When they had children they would be able to move into larger homes and as their children left home they would be given the opportunity to move back into the smaller sorts of units that they needed for their retiring years. Those sorts of flexible plans that allow for mobility are something that the Government ought to be looking at and encouraging in other areas.

As I said earlier, there is considerable concern in the community about problems in housing allocation. On 21 August of this year the Age ran an article headed `Housing allocation cut in real terms'. The article stated:
Public housing and the first home owners scheme will receive less money in real terms.
The article was referring to this year's Budget. It continued:
The total housing allocation rose by 5.2 per cent to $1,397 million, an effective reduction of about two per cent in real terms.
The first home owners scheme was allotted $290 million, the same as last year, an effective cut of about seven per cent.
The Victorian Government Minister for Housing, Mr Wilkes, made a plea to the Federal Government to reconsider its negative gearing proposals. The article stated that his Department alleged:
. . . the decision, which no longer allows investors to claim losses on property against other income, could add 87,000 families to the State's public housing waiting list.
It continued:
Mr Wilkes wanted a special grant so that the department could buy enough flats to meet the extra demand.

Whether the moneys being made available under the legislation before us today will satisfy Mr Wilkes is anybody's guess. I suspect, however, that he was talking in terms of a grant additional to that which we are looking at today. There is a very real concern that public sector housing is taking a nose dive. An article written last month in the Australian commented:
The housing industry showed patchy growth during July, with a strong rise in private-sector building approvals but a fall in public-sector go-aheads.
This information was obtained from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The article continued:

Private-sector approvals during the month rose by 8 per cent on the June figure to 13,008-a 2 per cent increase in seasonally adjusted terms-while approvals of public-sector homes and other residential buildings fell by 32 per cent to 814.

Total housing approvals were 13,822, a 4 per cent rise in absolute terms but a 0.7 per cent fall after seasonal adjustment. The value of buildings approved was down slightly from $1,423.8 million in June to $1,374.3 million in July.
Victoria showed strongest growth, with a 13 per cent rise in approvals to 3,610.

Queensland and Western Australia also experienced increases of a lesser degree. In a country which prides itself on being reasonably affluent, we cannot afford to face a future where there is a dearth of public housing and an increasing cost in private housing. If this legislation goes some way towards providing the States with the means to provide more families and individuals with a home, that will be all to the good. I do not think that we can stop at this point. We must look at using more Consolidated Revenue funds to provide people access either to the private rental market or to homes provided by the public sector in all States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate on the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1985, which is routine legislation. As Senator Messner and Senator Haines both said, this legislation comes up each year. The Opposition parties will not oppose it. For that, we are very grateful. I shall reflect for a moment on some of the things that Senator Haines said in her thoughtful speech on housing problems in general and in particular on the lack of public housing in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: All of us who have thought about the problems facing low income earners are well aware and have been aware since the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty some years ago that as a rule the biggest determinant of poverty is housing costs. The poorest people tend to be in private rental accommodation. This is exemplified in New South Wales figures on emergency relief. In excess of 50 per cent of the people receiving emergency relief in New South Wales are in fact private renters. They pay anything from 50 per cent to 60 per cent of their income in rent, compared with the average of 10 per cent to 15 per cent paid by those in public accommodation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even those people in private housing do not pay that percentage of their income. You were talking about people in private rental.
—People in private rental accommodation pay 50 per cent to 60 per cent. According to the New South Wales survey people in public housing in New South Wales pay on average about 15 per cent.
—But even those people who are buying homes are not allowed to spend that amount of money.

—Indeed. Senator Haines has brought up a problem that we have had in this country for a long time. We have had and still have a policy of encouraging home ownership, and I am not one of those people who condemn such a policy. I am very attracted to the work of a person who has had a good deal to do with the work of the South Australian Housing Trust. I refer to Hugh Stretton, who has pointed out in his very thoughtful articles that the encouragement of private ownership of housing is a very effective way of increasing housing stock. We also need public housing and, as Senator Haines has said, in a country as affluent as Australia this is one area that we have neglected in the past at both State and Federal level. But in recent times this Government and, in particular, the South Australian Government have concentrated as much as possible, within the limits of economic policy, on public housing. It has become a cliche, I know, but it remains a fact that the best way to assist people in our community in this difficult economic situation is to encourage economic growth and to get a vibrant and active economy. That is what the policy of this Government has been about.

SPEECH.PARA: We are in an extraordinary situation in that, having introduced our housing policies when we first came to government, we have seen the greatest recovery in the housing industry in this country in decades; yet we are sometimes implicitly criticised for doing too much in this area. We have to strike a balance between assistance for those who want access to private ownership and those who need public accommodation. That balance is not always easy to strike; but that is what the Government is about, in co-operation with most of the State governments. The South Australian Government, for instance, has been the major beneficiary of this legislation, particularly the nominating arrangements. The State has nominated the whole of its borrowing program for public housing in the past two years and in 1985-86. It therefore receives about $131m of these funds in 1985-86 on concessional terms and conditions. This will enable the South Australian Housing Trust-Western Australia is in the same situation-to do very much more in the area of public ownership than it has been able to do in the past. I have no real argument with most of the things that Senator Haines said. I think we are all very concerned with the very real problems which face disadvantaged people in this area in Australia.

I have a few problems with what Senator Messner said, as I always do. Before Senator Messner grew his beard, he liked to imitate Jeremiah. Since he has grown his beard he thinks he is Jeremiah. Every time he makes a speech in this place-again he made a speech today which bore no resemblance to the legislation before us-he gives us all a lecture on the evils of the Hawke Government and our economic policy. Today, the lecture we got was threefold. It was, firstly, about the evils of high interest rates and how the Hawke Labor Government had deliberately set about creating them; the second element was an extraordinary attack on our changes to negative gearing; and the third was the introduction of the capital gains tax.

While I was listening to Senator Messner saying that interest rates are too high-who can disagree with him when anyone who is paying off a mortgage knows that they are too high-and that the Hawke Government's policies would destroy this country, create unemployment and put everyone out of work, I was looking at today's Australian Financial Review. It points out, as everyone in the community knows, that unemployment is down and is continuing to fall; employment is up and is continuing to rise; inflation is down considerably on what it was when the previous Government went out of power; business confidence is increasing, according to the share index in the article on the front page of the newspaper; the number of industrial disputes is at a record low; the share market is up; and there is a general feeling of confidence in the community. Senator Messner always ignores those very cogent facts. When we were in opposition we referred to the fact that 250,000 people had been added to the unemployment list and inflation was rising at a rapid rate. The then Government is now on the Opposition benches and we are in government because of the things that were happening. We will stay here because we have reversed all those trends. That is the routine that Senator Messner goes through on any legislation he talks about.

Senator Messner then-as Senator Haines said in her speech, it was very difficult to understand his logic-had the gall to tell us that we were hitting the poor by abolishing negative gearing and introducing a very mild capital gains tax. He said that all the people who had been taking advantage of negative gearing and the fact that this was the only country in the world without a capital gains tax were doing so to help the poor in the community obtain low income accommodation. I am amazed that even Senator Messner would try to put that sort of line to honourable senators. We have had a problem of high private rents and insufficient rental accommodation in this country for over a decade. Negative gearing and the lack of a capital gains tax did not help to solve those problems at all, and the introduction of this relatively mild capital gains tax, in the view of most commentators, certainly will not have the diabolical effects which Senator Messner has mentioned.

He then said that the taxes are no good anyhow because they do not raise enough revenue. How these taxes, if in Senator Messner's view they will not raise enough revenue, will depress the housing market in the way he says they will is quite beyond us.

TALK.START.PARA: —He never lets the facts get in the way of a good idea.

—Some of us never spoil a good argument by using the facts, but on this occasion I am. I really thought Senator Messner would tell us that the introduction of the tax on free lunches also would affect the poor, but not even he would go that far.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation, as we all know, is routine. It provides funds to the States in the manner in which we have all talked about at various stages of this debate. I thank honourable senators for supporting the legislation and I assure them that the Government's policies will, as they have in the past, increase economic growth, increase employment, decrease unemployment and increase investment and business confidence generally in the community. In that way, the disadvantaged will be assisted as they have been in the past three years of our government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I had a question to ask, but as it was to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and he does not seem to be with us yet, I would prefer to wait until a little later in Question Time. Here he is. How nice. My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer him to the tabling in the House of Representatives yesterday of a letter from Mr Eddie Visbord, the acting head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Does the Minister agree that, whatever the actions of public servants, the Prime Minister must ultimately assume responsibility for what they do as well as for his own failings? Does the Minister further agree that in the Prime Minister's continual search for scapegoats he has failed to live up to the standards of ministerial responsibility put forward by members of the Australian Labor Party in recent years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney referred to the letter from Mr Visbord, and tabled by the Prime Minister, which adverted to a number of matters relating to the Australian Bicentennial Authority. I have always put the view that ultimately a Minister must accept responsibility for the advice which is given to him by his Department and for actions which are taken upon that advice. In respect of this matter the Prime Minister has accepted responsibility for actions taken on advice given to him by his Department.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the great concerns in the Bicentennial Authority issue-as it has now become known-is to what extent there was ministerial responsibility at all under the arrangement set up by the former Government for the administration of the Bicentennial Authority, and that was a view which was specifically put by Mr Reid, the Chairman of the Authority.

In accepting, as I do, the general concept of ministerial responsibility, if people want me to read the extracts from the lengthy discussion which has taken place on this topic in Australia over many years-particularly during the last five years of the previous Government, when the issue arose on many occasions in relation to a great variety of issues-I will do so.

The fact of the matter is that the fundamental issue which touched off the Visbord letter was the question of a missing letter in a file in the Prime Minister's Department. If honourable senators have read any of the statements which have been made in respect of ministerial responsibility they will know that I certainly do not accept the view that it is the obligation of a Prime Minister of this country to go through 800 files in his office.

TALK.START.PARA: —You expected me to go through a hundred thousand.

—No, we did not expect the honourable senator to go through 100,000; we just expected him to get one out of the bottom drawer of his desk where it had been for five years. We expected him to get all those call girls out of his office, and things like that. That is the sort of thing we expected of him. My answer to the question is that I do not see it as an issue in terms of ministerial responsibility for the Prime Minister of this country to perform the operation of a filing clerk in his Department.

—Mr President, I was fully prepared to comment on the slippery answer of the Leader of the Government. I ask a supplementary question. Does the Leader of the Government deny that the Prime Minister sought Dr Armstrong's resignation, over the objections of Mr Reid? Does he deny that Mr Reid sought and obtained the Prime Minister's approval for settlement terms? Does he deny that the Prime Minister urged Mr Reid to be generous in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not deny-in fact I assert-that the Prime Minister sought Dr Armstrong's resignation on the basis of advice from his Department, and the Prime Minister accepts full responsibility for that fact, and has from the commencement of this matter. I do not deny that the Prime Minister, by arrangement with Mr Reid, saw that Mr Reid supervised the terms of settlement with Dr Armstrong. Mr Reid always asserted that that was his right and the Prime Minister believed that that was his right in respect of the negotiations of terms of settlement.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a matter of public record that the Prime Minister said in some conversation or other-I cannot identify it at the moment-that Mr Reid, in looking at the total package, should err on the side of generosity. TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Resources and Energy seen the spurious advertisement which appeared in the West Australian on 26 September and which purported to inform residents of the Pilbara about the perks component of the Commonwealth Government's tax package? Is there anything in the advertisement which can be described as being remotely accurate? Can the Minister advise the Senate that the mining industry is well aware of the facts in this matter and will not be misled by this type of mischievous advertising?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had the opportunity to see and examine the misleading and irresponsible advertisement placed by the Liberal candidate for the Pilbara, Mr John Van Uden, in the West Australian under the sub-text `Let's tell the turkeys to get seasoned'; a quality of abuse which even Senator Chaney these days, with his new found sophisticated mode of interjection, I think cannot match. The estimates given in the advertisement are erroneous because they relate to the total value of the fringe benefits involved, not the taxation payable on those benefits. The tax payable would, on these grounds alone, be only a quarter of the figure quoted.

ANSWER.PARA: I will go through a couple of illustrations. The advertisement quotes a figure for subsidised rent of $80 per week. Assuming that in the Pilbara context this involves the difference between market rental of about $120 a week and actual payments by employees of $40 a week, the tax paid would in fact add up only to about $1,000 per annum, not the $4,000 per annum that is set out in the advertisement.

I do not have precise information concerning the cost of free water, power and rates. But even if we assume the figure of $2,000-odd per annum used in the advertisement, the tax payable would be less than $1,000.

The advertisement quotes two family return air fares per annum as being typical for the Pilbara. But the Australian Mining Industry Council, in its advice to us, had allowed for only one trip per annum in its estimates, although it appears that some companies may in fact be providing two trips. The AMIC estimate for the cost of each trip is approximately $1,700. As only half of the value of the trip is taxable, the tax payable on two trips per annum would amount in toto to about $800 per annum and not the $4,000 claimed in the advertisement. If one adds together the above estimates of tax payable, at around $2,800 per annum, the comparison is obvious with the $10,000 quoted in the advertisement.

The mining industry and the workers in the Pilbara would be well aware of the details of this matter and they will not be misled by such ignorant, irresponsible and manifestly politically motivated advertising. I mention finally that discussions have been held with industry representatives, both by my departmental officers and by officers from the Treasury, including discussions initiated by Senator Cook as Deputy Chairman of the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council. I am confident that as a result misleading, spurious and irresponsible advertisements of this kind will be seen for the charade that they are.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Richardson has always been regarded as a man of great generosity of spirit and on this occasion he has given some gratuitous advice. Senator Richardson is as entitled as any other person in the Senate, the Parliament or the community to give advice to the Prime Minister about what he should do. People do that in various ways-in this place, by telegram, by telephone or in other ways. Senator Richardson has apparently given some advice to the Prime Minister which he apparently announced through a loud hailer across King's Hall. —These `ho, ho's' coming from the Opposition members are the sorts of noises they usually make when they are contemplating a free lunch. I can understand Senator Richardson offering the piece of advice which he did, because it is consistent with the conclusions of the Senate Estimates Committee.
—Where is he?
—One has occasion to deal with people suffering disabilities, but not usually blindness. The Estimates Committee of which Senator Richardson is Chairman, had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: The Committee considers that the Prime Minister has to accept the ministerial responsibility for the Australian Bicentennial Authority. Nevertheless he was obviously not kept fully informed by his Department. The evidence indicates that officers of the Department displayed gross incompetence in their handling of this issue.
Senator Short, I must say, in fairness to him-

TALK.START.PARA: —Some Rhodes scholar he turned out to be.

—Yes, a real Rhodes scholar. Senator Short, in fairness to him, expressed a qualification about that, but I think that is a qualification which is looking after the interests of a particular peer group to which he belongs.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Michael Baume proceeding to address a supplementary question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is clearly not a supplementary question; it is an additional question. I rule it out of order.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. Has the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region established or put into effect any safety standards for disposing of contaminated water into the Magella catchment area of the Kakadu National Park? Has Ranger Uranium Mines Pty Ltd established or put into effect safety standards for disposing of contaminated water into the Magella catchment area of the Kakadu National Park? If the answer to those questions is yes, are the safety standards the same, or are they different in any way and, if so, in what way?

—Senator Cooney was kind enough to suggest that I might get some advice from the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, who has advised me that the spill of tailings on 24 September at the Ranger uranium mine was immediately and effectively cleaned up. The Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region has advised that the spillage was small and of little environmental consequence. The radiation exposure of workers would have been very small and well below the prescribed limit. The Acting Minister for Mines and Energy in the Northern Territory, who has the supervisory responsibility, discussed the incident with the Ranger management and Ranger ceased using the pipeline until it was completely rectified. The Commonwealth Government expresses its concern at the number of breakdowns of the tailing pipeline at the mine and expects Ranger Uranium Mines Pty Ltd to immediately tighten its control on the pipeline operation. To that extent the Commonwealth will consistently keep this matter under review.

—Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that because of petrol price discounting currently in New South Wales some people pay as low a figure as 42c a litre for super grade petrol, while others, especially in country areas, pay 59c? Is the Government not concerned that its petrol pricing policies are in such disarray that some people pay 17c a litre more than others-the highest figure I can remember? Is it not especially serious that the effect of these distortions is a disincentive to decentralisation in Australia? Since the present petrol pricing policy of the Government is plainly farcical, what does the Government propose to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Government's legislative authority to control retail prices, including petrol prices, is constrained to a very large degree by constitutional considerations, with that authority really lying with the States.
—You have been learning about the Constitution lately, have you?

—Not with any assistance from Senator Durack, with the utmost respect. While the Commonwealth has been able to operate a maximum wholesale prices surveillance system through the Prices Surveillance Authority, because of the co-operation of State and Territory governments and the oil industry, it does not have the power to enforce any PSA direction if the States or, more particularly, any part of the industry decide to ignore it. Actual retail prices, as Senator Mason no doubt will be aware, are set by the refining companies, their distributors and agents. These prices naturally reflect differences in supply costs and, more particularly, reflect differing degrees of competition. Consequently, they vary both over time as conditions change and as between outlets. The reality is that in discounting we are seeing a competitive market at work with all the advantages and disadvantages that may be perceived to flow from that. The problem of discounting, or more particularly the absence of it, is most acutely felt in country areas of Australia where there is less competition, or very often no competition at all. That is the primary explanation for the very substantial difference in price levels to which so many people have been drawing attention between metropolitan and country areas. There are also the added costs associated with freight to consumers in country areas and the higher wholesaling and retailing costs associated with smaller sales volume in those areas.

ANSWER.PARA: Any attempt to regulate petrol prices with a view to making them uniform, either as between the States or within the States as between different locations, will, the Government believes, introduce significant distortions into the operation of the market. Any savings made in costs in particular areas would only be short lived and could eventually give rise to major structural adjustment problems.

—The Government is acutely aware of the market opportunities for uranium that will exist in Europe, particularly in the latter part of the 1990s, as indeed is the case elsewhere in the world, even if the market capacity to absorb additional uranium is at the moment pretty tight. We are actively encouraging not only the existing uranium producers but also the Roxby Downs joint venturers to seek to get into those markets and engage in continuing discussion with them about ways in which that might be assisted. It is not the Government's belief that the embargo on the supply of uranium for end use in France has, in fact, affected in any way Australia's commercial reputation, or the probability of our becoming a major supplier of uranium to Europe in the future. The circumstances of that embargo are extremely well known and well understood and, I believe, appreciated. It is essentially seen as a bilateral matter, as it is between Australia and France. The possible supply of Australian uranium for end use in France would require both a decision by France to seek such uranium and the willingness of someone to supply it. France has shown no inclination to disturb the present situation by seeking Australian uranium from any third parties, and so long as the present situation continues we do not see the embargo having consequences of any kind for the supply of Australian uranium to other Euratom countries.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer the Minister to the view held by some elements in the community, which view is being fostered by the Northern Territory Government and certain Opposition members, that the Federal Government is in the process of handing over vast tracts of prime pastoral land to the Aboriginal people to the disadvantage of non-Aboriginal residents. Is this an accurate account of the true situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of statements have been made in recent times with respect to the symbolic gesture with which this Government is associated-the handing over of Ayers Rock to the Aboriginal people. A consequence of that action has been a number of statements which suggest an inaccurate picture has been drawn from the debate that has taken place. In preparation for the debate, I sought certain information, which has now come into my possession. I was not able to discuss it in full yesterday because of the way in which the debate took place. But what is indicated is that of the Northern Territory pastoral properties, 18.2 per cent are owned by individuals, and 38.4 per cent are owned by Northern Territory companies, which it is suggested include many companies with foreign shareholdings; and 37.4 per cent of pastoral properties in the Northern Territory are under foreign ownership, including such well known international figures as Nelson Bunker Hunt, the Sultan of Sabah, Kerry Packer, Lord Vestey and other similar-type foreign owners, as well as some Australian nationals. According to figures supplied to me by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, it appears that in 1983 Aborigines--
—On a point of order, Mr President, I think it is quite out of order to call Kerry Packer a foreigner; it is Rupert Murdoch who is a foreigner.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I am sure there are other notorious people involved in such ownerships. ANSWER.PARA: I was handed a document this morning which I find rather disturbing. It shows copies of advertisements placed in a Northern Territory newspaper in Alice Springs in 1982 saying:
Any person found trespassing, shooting or camping on--

Trespassers will be shot. Survivors will be prosecuted.

It would appear that, whilst many views have been expressed regarding the access of Australians to Aboriginal properties, it is pretty clear that Aborigines are not permitted to go on to properties owned by pastoral companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries whose activities in 1973 and 1978 disrupted world economic activity. I ask the Minister: Can he report on the implications for Australia of the recent Vienna meeting of OPEC, particularly the pressure from six of its 13 members to exceed their production quotas for crude oil? What are the possible budgetary consequences and implications for Australian coal and other energy industries of the moves at the OPEC Conference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been widely reported in the Press that the two-day OPEC meeting on 3 and 4 October in Vienna broke up in disarray. As expected, the major stumbling block was the question of production quotas, or the division of OPEC's share of the market amongst its members. No new agreement was arrived at, the major stumbling block being Saudi Arabia's indication that it was no longer prepared to produce at below its quota level and also its revelation confirming reports in recent weeks that it had entered into arrangements to sell quantities of oil at what were effectively discount prices. The inability of OPEC to make clear decisions with regard to production quotas certainly does not augur well for the Organisation. A number of nations are likely to increase output whenever the market permits. Among those reportedly seeking increases in their production quotas were Iraq, Iran, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Gabon and Ecuador, with Ecuador threatening to leave OPEC unless its quota was increased. All this could add significantly to available world supplies over the coming months.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the case that recently the oil market has been stronger as a result of increasing demand due to the onset of the northern winter and the disruption flowing from Iraqi attacks on Iranian oil institutions. But it can be expected that this situation would be reversed if OPEC production discipline is weak, as seems presently to be the case, and a steep fall in prices could consequently result in the latter part of the northern winter if not sooner. It has been the case in recent weeks that a number of OPEC officials, including Sheikh Yamani and the President of OPEC, Dr Subroto, had been warning OPEC and non-OPEC countries alike to restrain output to avert a major reduction in prices. The consequences for Australia of a major oil price drop would, in the Government's estimate, be mixed.

There are a number of negatives. First, in the short term, there would be a major decline in government revenue which would either blow out the deficit or force new or increased taxation elsewhere. In the longer term we face difficulty with our energy exports-petroleum, coal and liquefied natural gas, coming on stream soon-with potentially lower prices and possibly lower volumes. That, in turn, flows through to the prospect of diminution in oil exploration activity. Further, with our trade concentrated in agricultural and mining products rather than manufactures or services, we could not be expected to share proportionately in the benefits that would flow to the large industrialised nations from a major drop in oil prices, although it is true that to compensate for that there could be a lagged improvement in market conditions for minerals and metal products.

On the negative side, there would also be a potentially massive pressure on the world's banking system if a price drop were of such a magnitude that it so reduced the revenues of countries such as Nigeria, Mexico and Venezuela that they became unable to service their huge external debts. The effects of this would then flow through to all the Western economies, including Australia.

On the more positive side, a substantial drop in oil prices-apart from being of benefit to motorists and consumers-would lead to some lowering of inflation and the cost structure for industry, an effective increase in income by all petroleum product users and a likely increase in economic activity in at least some sectors of the Australian economy as well as in the international economy in general.

In summary, this is an important issue; it has certainly been the subject of a lot of newspaper comment in recent days. There would be winners and losers flowing from such a situation. Australia's energy-producing industries would certainly be harmed, but there could be subsequent improvements for some other industries, including minerals production and processing, as economic activity picks up around the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about agriculture and the benefits to farmers?

—I referred to motorists as consumers, but of course the farming sector is also a very significant consumer of petroleum products. It might be expected that, overall, difficult short to medium term problems of structural adjustment would arise and on balance it is difficult to predict the net result.

—I address my question to the Minister representing both the Special Minister of State and the Attorney-General. In light of the report in the National Times on the Norfolk Island Ouvea bungle, based on the Minister's replies to Australian Democrat questions, will the Government now tell us why, given the fact that the crew were arrested by Australian police on 15 and 16 July, an urgent check was not carried out on their passports before these documents were returned by the Norfolk Island Administration? Would the Government agree that the inconsistencies and confusion in the replies to questions on the Australian aspect of the Rainbow Warrior bombing indicates that the impression grows of `a giant bungle on Norfolk Island'? Will the Government now give a full, frank and detailed explanation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept that there have been inconsistencies or confusion in any of the information that has been put on the record by me or anyone else about this affair. To round out some of the answers that have been given in light of Senator Sanders's question, I add the following on behalf of the Special Minister of State and the Attorney-General: Information given to the Government by the Norfolk Island authorities is that, while the three members of the crew of the Ouvea were in custody on 15 and 16 July, New Zealand police officers on Norfolk Island initiated an urgent check on the validity of their passports. That check involved, as it does with passports, communication with French authorities through Interpol. Checks of this nature, irrespective of the country involved, take days, if not longer.

ANSWER.PARA: The crew members were released on 16 July because, first, no evidence was found on the Ouvea to justify their continued detention under section 9 of the Norfolk Island Police Offences Ordinance. Secondly, there was no evidence to hand to suggest that their passports were invalid or false. Thirdly, no request for the extradition of the men had been made by New Zealand. Accordingly, there was simply no lawful basis for the continued detention of the men, their property or their passports.

As to the latter parts of Senator Sanders's question, I simply say that the answer I gave to the Senate on Wednesday set out the facts as they were known to the Government. The only fact that was known to the Government that has not so far been mentioned was one advised to me a few moments ago by the Minister for Territories. He said that, far from this incident being perceived as a `bungle', to use Senator Sanders's language, the Norfolk Island Administration had been complimented by the New Zealand authorities for its handling of the matter.
In further response to Senator Sanders's rhetoric, I believe I have given on behalf of the Government as full, as frank and as detailed an explanation of this matter as it is possible to give.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment to the article in the Bulletin of 8 October regarding the 158 per cent increase in profits of the mineral sand miner, Consolidated Rutile Ltd, in which the Chairman of Murphyores Incorporated Pty Ltd, Mr Bill Murphy, is reported to have secured from the shadow Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Durack, an undertaking that a conservative Federal government would lift export bans applying to mineral sands projects and return the control of such projects, including Moreton and Fraser Islands, to the States? Can the Minister comment on the implications of this undertaking?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article and I think that honourable senators generally will appreciate that along the eastern seaboard of Australia there are many unique ecosystems and it is very important that there be some understanding between Commonwealth and State governments about the preservation of these areas. In my own State of New South Wales there has been a development of attitudes in recent time which has put into practice a recognition of that important principle. The areas to which I am referring are in the northern part of New South Wales particularly, and in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: The coastal areas of south-east Queensland where mineral sands have been mined include some priceless and unique ecosystems which are very fragile and susceptible to disturbance. Therefore the matter must be dealt with very carefully by any public authority or private organisation which is given the rights to exploit the sands. These areas include recreational areas that are accessible to lower income groups, unlike Noosa and Gold Coast penthouses with fabulous views so often publicly admired by such people as the Queensland Premier and his wife.

I believe the Opposition policy is short-sighted in that it will encourage the development of these other areas in a manner which suggests that the environment should not be protected. We should adopt a tender care approach to such projects to counter the outrageous statement by the Queensland Mines Minister, Ivan Gibbs, who said:
We have rationalised sand mining in a way that would get rid of all the contentious areas.

That is a rather capricious approach and one that should be deprecated. We would indeed get rid of all the contentious areas if we had the policy of rehabilitation similar to that which led to such poor management as was encountered on Stradbroke Island in 1982. There are other examples of one having to be very careful about the way in which one approaches these matters.

It is clear that the Queensland Government is reluctant to enforce the condition that the original topography be restored after mining, as it is in New South Wales. Therefore, if we are to protect these important areas-and that is an absolutely essential requirement for the Queensland Government-we should be concerned about the Opposition spokesman's statements. If we give export licences for development of rutile mining willy-nilly, there will be significant long term ecological damage. To that extent, while this Government is in office it will certainly apply strict and stringent controls on the development of sand mining anywhere in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance seen the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics unemployment figures? If so, will the Minister join me in congratulating the Queensland Government on its performance in creating 20 per cent of the 41,900 jobs for Queenslanders? Will he also congratulate the 13,000 southerners who have fled southern Labor-controlled States to come to the State which has the fastest rate of employment growth in the nation? Does the Minister agree with me that this growth is hardly surprising when one considers that the Queensland economy has above average performances in exports, retail sales, capital expenditure, construction activity and home ownership levels and the fact that the Queensland Government has given Australian employers a lead in standing up to union excesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the latest employment figures which show that there were 56,000 additional jobs at the end of September compared with the end of August, according to the ABS survey, and that the national unemployment rate, in spite of a very significant increase in the participation rate, has fallen to 8.1 per cent. That means that since the National Economic Summit of 1983 almost half a million new jobs have been created and inflation has fallen to almost half the level it was at that time. There are fewer industrial disputes than there have been for the previous 18 years. Unit wage costs have fallen to the lowest level since 1970. We have had two years, and are entering a third year, of real economic growth of the order of 5 per cent, something which has not happened before in Australia. All of those things, of course, are attributable to the accord. Some of the benefits of the accord spin off into Queensland, as they do everywhere else.

ANSWER.PARA: It is astonishing, if I may say so, that the Leader of the Opposition, confronted with that evidence, should turn his back on the accord and its demonstrable success and gleefully anticipate five years of industrial warfare under a deregulated or decentralised labour market. Not even Malcolm Fraser at his worst ever gleefully anticipated five years of industrial warfare as the present Opposition Leader does. The Opposition's Deputy Leader yesterday also criticised the accord, something he had done on 24 September following the release of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report and his apparent misunderstanding of it. Between 24 September and yesterday-that is, the beginning of last week-he stepped right away from his Leader's policy on wages deregulation and a free market for labour. He was at one extreme, he went to the other extreme, and now he is back where he started in the first place. Sometimes it is difficult to determine with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition what his real preference is. The OECD report to which I referred was described by Mr Brown in these terms:
The OECD report on unemployment should give the Government cold comfort. Nor is there anything in the report to justify the present course the Government has embarked upon.
That was of course completely in conflict with not only the facts in the report but also the facts which are revealed in the economic statistics I have cited.

Senator Boswell said that employment had grown by 20 per cent in Queensland. I do not know whether it is precisely 20 per cent. I think the most recent figures reflect the same percentage as Queensland's proportion of the total population and, as I recall, Queensland still has the highest unemployment rate of any State. What is really critical is that for the last two and a half years the Australian economy has performed in a way which by Australian standards has been quite spectacular: Three years of real growth of 5 per cent, half a million new jobs, the inflation rate halved, industrial disputes at an 18-year record low and the lowest unit wage costs since 1970. I find it quite extraordinary that, confronted with that record, there could be extremists like the Leader of the Opposition who want to throw all that aside and who salivate at the prospect of five years of industrial warfare.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Further, is it not true that by these means a crafty reduction in the unemployment statistics, but not in the real numbers of those unable to find permanent and productive work, has been engineered for the coming year?

—Has the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs noted the reported statement of the Opposition shadow spokesman on foreign affairs, Mr Peacock, that a coalition government `would have striven to keep the ANZUS Treaty operative'? Is this statement consistent with Mr Peacock's earlier repeated calls for Australia to establish a bilateral treaty with the United States if New Zealand did not change its ships visit policy within three months of an Australian ultimatum? Would calls by the Leader of the National Party and Opposition shadow defence spokesman, Mr Sinclair, for economic sanctions against New Zealand have assisted Australia and the United States to keep the ANZUS Treaty operative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted the recent claim by the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, Mr Peacock, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 23 September, that a coalition government `would have striven to keep the ANZUS Treaty operative'. I note that that stands in very direct and stark contrast to his repeated earlier calls for Australia to initiate moves to establish a bilateral treaty with the United States in place of ANZUS. If the Hawke Government had adopted the Opposition's earlier approach of placing ultimatums and even economic sanctions on New Zealand, Australia would manifestly have jeopardised our very close relationship with New Zealand without achieving anything in relation to New Zealand's policy on ship visits. Instead, the Hawke Government has pursued a consistent policy of seeking to preserve Australia's national interests in our relationships with both our ANZUS partners despite the current policy differences between New Zealand and the United States.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's relationship with the United States is firmly established beyond any challenge. The ANZUS Treaty reflects a coincidence of strategic interests between the United States and Australia that goes far beyond the terms of that Treaty. Defence co-operation between Australia and the US includes the joint facilities, combined exercises, technology transfers, intelligence exchanges and continuing consultation on international issues. While New Zealand is fully aware that the Australian Government does not share its views on the question of the allied ship visits, the Hawke Government has maintained Australia's important interests in its relations with New Zealand. Australia and New Zealand have common strategic concerns, particularly in the South Pacific region, and these are reflected in continuing co-operation in the defence field, including bilateral exercises and intelligence exchanges. These national interests are not to be lightly sacrificed, as they would have been had Australia pursued the ill-considered and heavy footed policies which have been advocated by the coalition parties.

The Hawke Government will safeguard Australia's interests in our relations with both the United States and New Zealand, whatever may occur in relations between the United States and New Zealand. I make the point finally that our consistent, careful and moderate approach on this whole issue stands in very sharp contrast with the strident vacillation of our opponents.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Chipp asked me in my capacity as Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs a question about ANZUS in a number of parts. I undertook to give him a considered supplementary answer. Since it is a substantial answer, I seek leave to incorporate the text in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

1. This Government can not be accused of misleading the Australian public about the meaning of the provisions of the ANZUS Treaty. Indeed, the Government has gone to some lengths to dispel popular misconceptions about ANZUS and to clarify its value and effectiveness.
In the opening sentences of his statement to Parliament (on 15 September 1983) on the outcome of the review of ANZUS undertaken when this Government came into office, Mr Hayden said:

``. . . I do not say that the Treaty guarantees Australia's national security and welfare, nor do I place us in that posture of happy dependence that has satisfied the foreign policy ambitions of many Australians in the past both within and without this Parliament.''

Further on in that same statement, in discussing the conclusions reached as a result of that review (including formal discussions at the Washington meeting of the ANZUS Council in July that year), Mr Hayden said:

Support from Treaty partners can be expressed in a range of responses. The Treaty does not provide any automatic guarantee of military support in the event of attack or major threat. We were reassured by the Americans as to their understanding of the requirement for prompt and effective fulfilment of ANZUS obligations. As Secretary of State Shultz said at the joint press conference following the Council meeting: `. . . the hard kernel is the undertaking to respond in the event of attack on any of the countries involved'. In the United States view any armed attack on the ally would require, and would receive from the other allies, full and prompt fulfilment of the ANZUS security commitment-including, if necessary military support. But, as I said at the same press conference, and as Mr Shultz acknowledged earlier at the ANZUS Council meeting, the obligation to repond and to assist would not automatically involve the provision of military forces in support of the country subjected to threat or attacks-because of the requirement to observe constitutional processes. These would allow each country opportunity to assess the requirements of the situation and to determine its national interests and obligations and the mode and extent of its response. A range of responses might be available, and it would be up to the other partners to judge which response would be appropriate in a given situation. It may be in certain circumstances that diplomatic action, or political or economic sanctions against the adversary, or the supply of equipment or military logistical support for the ally would be judged a more appropriate response than direct military involvement. In other circumstances direct military support may be appropriate.
Those points have been consistently stressed by Mr Hayden and Ministerial colleagues in their major public statements on ANZUS since then.

2. As there are no foreign bases on Australian soil, the question presumably refers to the joint Australian-US defence facilities, the general purpose and functions of which were explained by the Prime Minister in his statement to Parliament on 6 June 1984.

As the Prime Minister noted then and as he and other Ministers have noted on several occasions since then, the Government accepts that in certain circumstances the joint facilities could be nuclear targets in the event of a nuclear conflict and that in that sense the hosting of the facilities does bring with it some degree of added risk of nuclear attack.

In passing, though, I would draw to the honourable senator's attention remarks made during a visit to Australia earlier this year by Mr Victor Afanasyev, editor-in-chief of the official Soviet Communist Party newspaper, Pravda, to the effect that, if war broke out between the superpowers, the Soviet Union would not attack Australia with nuclear weapons and would ``probably not strike'' against the joint Australian-US defence facilities.
As we cannot enter into the minds of possibly hostile foreign military planners, it is not possible to be categoric about the specific risk of nuclear attack on the joint facilities.
Our intelligence and defence authorities have for many years now assessed the risk of nuclear war as remote and improbable, provided effective deterrence is maintained.

As Australia would suffer the consequences of nuclear war whether or not we have the facilities, as we cannot therefore gain immunity by removing the facilities, and as the facilities contribute fundamentally to deterrence of nuclear war, the Government firmly believes that the tangible benefit of their contribution to avoidance of nuclear war outweighs any possible future risk to our security through our hosting of the facilities.
