DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The implications for the principle of ministerial responsibility arising out of the Prime Minister's handling of the $500,000 payment to the former Chief Executive of the Australian Bicentennial Authority.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the matter of public importance which we have brought forward for discussion by the Senate is that which you have just read, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The implications for the principle of ministerial responsibility arising out of the Prime Minister's handling of the $500,000 payment to the former Chief Executive of the Australian Bicentennial Authority.

Until yesterday Parliament, through the House of Representatives and Senate Estimates Committee A, has been dealing with a controversy over the removal of Dr Armstrong from the Australian Bicentennial Authority. Over the last month or so the personal involvement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has gradually unravelled. Until yesterday the central issue was the display of the Prime Minister's incompetence. He had shown his lack of administrative skills, his failure to admit his role until he was forced to by journalists and by parliamentary action, including that taken within the Senate Estimates Committee, his failure to be open, frank, truthful and, most significantly, his failure in the course of this matter to ask questions which any sensible man would have asked.

It is important to note that right through this period the key issue which has been raised and pursued is the personal involvement of the Prime Minister in this whole matter. It is not some distant affair that involves his Department; it is a matter that involves the Prime Minister and his personal actions. It is a matter in which he has had the closest possible involvement. It is a matter in which, notwithstanding what was said by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in answer to a question today about the independence of the Bicentennial Authority, it is quite apparent that the Authority acted on the urging and, indeed, the instruction of the Prime Minister with respect to Dr Armstrong.

Yesterday, in the course of this unhappy affair, Mr Hawke played the last card. He played the card of a scoundrel. He set out to blame everybody else and particularly set out to blame his Department. The Opposition believes that Mr Hawke-the Prime Minister-has been guilty of a cowardly act. We believe that he has been guilty of an unprincipled act and an act which flies in the face of the way that the system of government in Australia is supposed to be conducted.

We should have some pity for poor Mr Visbord, the loyal public servant whose lengthy letter of regret was put forward in the House of Representatives yesterday. I suppose we may never know how that letter came to be written. It may, of course, be the final act of loyalty by Mr Visbord. The sad and shameful fact of the matter is that our ever-diminishing Prime Minister set out to hide behind that letter from Mr Visbord. In the view of the Opposition the issue now is what the Government is doing to distort and destroy the principles under which government is conducted in this country.

Let us look at Mr Hawke's direct personal involvement in the whole matter and at his attempts to extricate himself from it and to cover it up. On 15 August of this year the Prime Minister instructed the Chairman of the Australian Bicentennial Authority to terminate Dr Armstrong's services. It is clear from the paper which was tabled by the Prime Minister that he urged that action against the wishes of the Chairman of the Authority, Mr Reid. It is evident from the public record that the Prime Minister knew that Dr Armstrong could not be sacked for misconduct and that any termination had to be by way of an agreed settlement. It is quite clear that the Prime Minister told Mr Reid that this matter had to be dealt with speedily so that he could have an answer to questions which might be raised when Parliament resumed on 20 August. When Mr Reid wrote to him on 19 August, having complied with his instructions, in a letter which set out the nature and broad terms of settlement, including the fact that there would have to be consideration for restraints on the retiring Chief Executive, the Prime Minister's response was to tell Mr Reid to err on the side of generosity. Mr Reid, in the context of that conversation, told the Prime Minister that the settlement would be expensive and that it would cost more than $400,000.

If there was any point at which the Prime Minister should have been put on notice that he should make some inquiries, it was surely then. On the knowledge that he had of the position of Dr Armstrong, it was quite clear that the sum of money was about equivalent to the full amount-indeed, it may have been more-that would have been paid to Dr Armstrong had he served his full course. I would have thought that any prudent man, let alone a Prime Minister who was a Rhodes Scholar, would have been put on inquiry by the citing of that figure. Subsequently, the Prime Minister received the Chairman's letter of 28 August which set out the specific terms of settlement. The letter sought the authority of the Prime Minister for the settlement, the Prime Minister being the Minister responsible for the Bicentennial Authority. The Prime Minister, by his letter of 30 August, in full knowledge of the details, told the Chairman to proceed. Over a period of weeks the Prime Minister knew what was happening and that it was happening pursuant to his instructions. His intervention was that the matter should be dealt with generously.

Over a very lengthy period, therefore-over the whole period certainly-the Prime Minister had every opportunity to seek advice, legal or otherwise. He had the whole of his Department at his disposal to check and ensure the validity of the Bicentennial Authority's actions. In fact, there was no action by the Prime Minister, no objection by him, and the settlement proceeded. Of course, it proceeded after the man who had to sign the cheque took the trouble to contact the Department and was told to proceed. All this started to come forth only after a journalist, Mr Laurie Oakes, published articles which indicated that this had occurred. Of course, we then had a series of parliamentary actions which have gradually drawn the facts from the Prime Minister, other Ministers and the Department. I believe that the facts we have had to this point speak for themselves. The Prime Minister has now sought to blame his public servants, and his henchman and numbers man, Senator Richardson, has said publicly that public servants should be penalised and shifted because of what has occurred.

It is relatively easy to make judgments in this matter about the rights and wrongs of the situation. We in the Opposition-the Liberal and National parties-have so often heard the views of the Australian Labor Party, in opposition and in government, on the standards which apply in these matters. It has been very interesting to hear the Government appeal to precedent in terms of the problems which flowed from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the problems faced by Senator Durack as Attorney-General in respect of matters which occurred in his Department. That has been referred to frequently in the Senate this week. It was referred to on radio by Senator Richardson this morning. That is a matter which Senator Evans, the failed Attorney-General, Mr Hawke, Mr Young, Mr Hayden and all the luminaries of the Labor Party when in opposition said warranted the resignation of a Minister.

Let us contrast the facts in that case which has been appealed to by the Labor Party as a precedent. In those circumstances the relevant Minister, the then Attorney-General, had no personal knowledge of the matters which had occurred. There was no suggestion that there was any way in which he could have had personal knowledge. There was no suggestion that it was a matter on which he had given instructions or in which he had been involved. It was not a significant single matter of the sort which is under the direct control of the Prime Minister, as in this case. Instead, it was one of the tens of thousands of cases being considered by his Department at that time. Statistics show that the Crown Solicitor's Office dealt with more than 100,000 matters in 1980-81 and more than 80,000 in 1981-82. This was one matter that was being dealt with by an officer of the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth.

It is instructive to see what followed the disclosure of that maladministration within the Attorney-General's Department at that time. It was dealt with by inquiry and officers who were found to be at fault were dealt with by normal administrative and legal processes. They were not dealt with by the numbers man of some political party claiming that they should be dealt with in some ad hoc fashion. We can also see the contrast between the behaviour then and the behaviour now in the way in which the then Attorney-General, Senator Durack, drew attention to the very good general record of his Department, admitted that it had areas of difficulty and where there has been breakdowns-as occurs in any big organisation-and pointed to the way in which these matters were being rectified by the Government. He did not hide in a craven fashion behind the Public Service. There was no political attempt to take it out on the Public Service, such as has gone on in such an unedifying way over the last few days.

The Prime Minister, in putting this letter before the Parliament and in having his great friend and henchman, Senator Richardson, carry on about what ought to be done with these public servants, gives us examples of behaviour which is not fit behaviour for a Prime Minister, as it would not be fit behaviour for any Minister or any back bencher. The Prime Minister has been directly and personally involved. The Bicentennial Authority, which is subject to the direction of the Minister and which deals with funds that are subject to the control and the appropriation of the Government-as the Bicentennial Authority said when it settled this matter, it is entitled to spend money only in accordance with what the Government requires-was told by the Government that it should proceed. We have no evidence of the Prime Minister making any of the inquiries any sensible person would have made with respect to these matters.

On the one hand, the Government appeals to precedent and says that, after all, there have been difficulties before and Senator Durack did not resign, when Senator Durack had nothing to do with the matters that occurred within his Department and in this circumstance the Prime Minister was directly involved and was the moving force in the matter. On the other hand, the Prime Minister suddenly found great reserves of energy and conscience after his involvement was exposed. He showed no signs of activity or life until that exposure occurred. All this is quite damning. It is quite obvious, on the face of things, that the Prime Minister had not lived up to his responsibilities. The worst feature of the matter is that he is now seeking to hide behind those who are there to serve him. We have no evidence that they were even asked to examine this matter in a way which could have given a prudent Prime Minister independent advice.

In terms of the standards that are supposed to be applied, many quotations from Government members are very relevant. They are all statements which have been uttered when they have been seeking to apply standards to members of the party to which I belong or to members of the National Party of Australia. Mr Lionel Bowen, as recently as this year, referred to the difficulties with respect to extradition treaties which enabled Mr Trimbole to escape legal custody when he was arrested in Ireland. Mr Bowen said, when commenting on what had occurred with respect to that treaty over the preceding years, including the years when the now Opposition was in government, that he did not blame departmental officials. In his Press release of 27 March he said:
It is a matter of who is the boss-the Minister at the time.

I do not care and I do not believe that the people of Australia care that Mr Visbord is sorry that the Department was not able to proffer some advice to the Prime Minister, when all the evidence is that the Prime Minister acted so much off his own bat and there is no evidence that he sought the advice that would have enabled him to avoid the errors into which he fell.

We have had many debates in this place about the standards which should be applied. The person who has been most ready and vocal in insisting that high standards should be applied is the failed Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans. He carried the political consequences of his own failure in the office of Attorney-General. He is the man who promised so much and delivered so little. I note that he was to speak in this debate but he has been withdrawn. I consider that a very prudent move in view of the fact that so much of what he has said on this issue in the past can be quoted. What did he say about the subject of ministerial responsibility when he was claiming that Senator Durack was responsible for one of the one in 100,000 files which existed in his Department? This morning we heard the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, asking whether we expected the Prime Minister to go through 800 files. One might have asked Senator Button whether he expected Senator Durack to go through 100,000 files to find which ones might not have been getting immediate attention from the officers of his Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister's files are not in the bottom drawer of his desk.

—That is typical of the misleading, slippery approach which is adopted by the Leader of the Government in the Senate-this man who hides behind a smile to disguise untruths. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, in Question Time today, and again by that interjection, has sought to imply that files were in the bottom drawer of the desk of the Attorney-General when he knows that is an untruth, that is gilding the lily and that is a lie. The fact of the matter is that we have had a series of lectures read to us by members of the Labor Party of Australia with respect to the responsibility of Ministers. If we go back to what Senator Gareth Evans has had to say we find that in 1982, when this was a matter of major political importance, we had Senator Evans quoting a Liberal leader, Mr Fraser. Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: But . . . they must be the standards which the Prime Minister set or has talked about over a long period. This was going to be a Government without impropriety. In 1972 he said--
that is, Mr Fraser-
If a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia--
Then there are various interpolations and Senator Gareth Evans continued:
and if the Minister were unaware of it, the Minister should accept responsibility for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign.
The next day, when questions were raised about the real responsibility of Senator Durack, he said:
He is the Minister responsible for everything that happens within his Department.
Later in the same debate he said:
. . . why didn't it become known to you? Why didn't you ask the right questions in 1978?

Those are the sorts of standards which were being insisted upon by the Labor Party in those days. They are a long way from the standards which the Prime Minister is adopting when he hides behind his public servants and when his leading numbers man denigrates those public servants and says that they should be moved. That is a fine response to an area to which the Prime Minister has made such a deep personal contribution.

I do not think there is very much doubt about the way in which the public sees this very unsavoury matter. It was interesting to see in this morning's Canberra Times that Mr Pryor de- picted the Prime Minister as a goatherd sleeping under a tree. I think that is a very interesting and illustrative view. Of course, we have no mention of the Opposition in this matter but instead a Prime Minister who is sleeping under a tree. I do not believe that the Prime Minister was asleep on 19 August when he was told by Mr Reid that payments in excess of $400,000 would be made to the Chief Executive of the Bicentennial Authority. I wonder where the letter of 19 August from Mr Reid was kept. Perhaps it was in the Prime Minister's personal bottom drawer and that is why his Department did not get to see it. Perhaps the problem is that the Prime Minister's bottom drawer has been involved in this whole exercise. I thought that Mike Steketee summarised it all very well in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. In a lengthy article headed `Mr Hawke still ducking the Bicentennial wave', Mr Steketee said:

But Mr Hawke is prepared to blame everyone but himself for the administrative and political lapses involved. He was kept in the dark, he was misled, his department had failed to pass on information. But none of it was the Prime Minister's fault.

That is the claim of this ever-diminishing Prime Minister. Nothing is his fault although he was the moving force in the dismissal! He was the man who approved the general approach and the terms which were entered into by the Bicentennial Authority. Mr Hawke now stands as someone who has shown himself to be administratively incompetent. He is now wearing the tattered robe of the unprincipled and he has unleashed his numbers man on to his own Department. He has ignored the fundamental principle which should govern his exercise of the great responsibilities of the Prime Ministership. We believe that this whole episode has exposed the Prime Minister in a very shabby light indeed. We believe that he stands condemned for his inactivity, his incompetence and now for his shameful hiding behind his public servants who are his responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I have never lobbied the Prime Minister-as he will testify-in any shape or form, for or against Dr Armstrong. I would bow to people such as Senator Short and Senator Sir John Carrick, who were on the Estimates Committee and have studied these things in detail. They would know a lot more about the detail of this, but I just briefly place on record, without going to his defence, that as far as I am concerned the Prime Minister has done nothing improper, dishonest or reprehensible in this affair.

That leads to the question of ministerial responsibility which Senator Chaney quite properly has brought before the Senate. In the 25 years that I have been here I have heard lots of definitions of when a Minister should resign under the Westminster system. Quite frankly, with the exception of four or five cases, I have not seen examples of where he should have resigned. For example, I think it was quite wrong for Senator Withers to have been forced to resign when he did. I did not think that that was a resignable offence. I single out that event because I would like to be favourable to people. I think the rule of thumb is that if a Minister knows about something and does nothing about it, and that results in unnecessary cost to the taxpayer or a wrong-doing, surely that is a sackable or resignable offence.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister did know.

—I am just stating the offence; I am not putting a point of view. There is an extension of that, with which I think all honourable senators would agree: If a Minister ought to have known something but did not know and did not bother to find out, that also could be said to be a resignable offence. I am not in a position to judge whether the Prime Minister ought to have known. I have never been a Prime Minister. I have been a Minister eight or nine times and, God knows, that is a busy enough life.

SPEECH.PARA: I have jotted down one or two other incidental things in which the Prime Minister was mixed up during this time-the tax reform package, the Rainbow Warrior bombing, the South Pacific Treaty and the Budget. Those are the sorts of things that come across a Prime Minister's desk approximately 18 hours a day. I am of the view that it is an academic argument as to whether the Prime Minister ought to have known or ought to have found out more about the letter of 19 August and the Bicentenary. I have some sympathy with a busy Prime Minister, and every person who has occupied that office while I have been a member of this place has been guilty at some time or other of not knowing something that theoretically he ought to have known. Therefore, whilst I say that Senator Chaney has acted perfectly properly and has done the Senate a service in raising this matter today, I think that it is very difficult to be specific about when a Minister should or should not resign.

Having said that, I believe that the Prime Minister has made a classic mistake in this affair. Maybe he made it because of his being too kind-hearted. I do not know the reason, and I shall not advance one. I have had a lot of experience in these matters, because I have occupied a job as executive director, having as my boss a board, or a council or whatever. I have the old-fashioned idea that the job of the executive director is to carry out the instructions of the board or the council. A good executive director will not only be a good implementer of policy; he will also be creative and put creative ideas up to the board. We now reach, in this course of logic, this position: If the $20m spent by the Authority had been spent badly-and I am not saying whether it was, but one would wonder about $19m being spent on salaries and only $3m on projects-surely the question should have been asked: Did the Executive Director carry out the functions of the Board?. If the Board was at fault, the Board should have been sacked.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it was all reappointed by the Hawke Government.

—That may be so. Senator Sir John Carrick might wish to attribute blame, and that would be his right. I am trying to talk in principle. Surely the only two reasons to sack Dr Armstrong would have been, first, that he had been guilty of misconduct-and there has been no suggestion of that-or, secondly, that he had refused to carry out or had carried out incompetently or inefficiently the functions of the Board.
—And there is no evidence of that.

—There is no evidence and no suggestion of that. If anyone should have been sacked, I should have thought that the first cabs off the rank would have been Mr Reid and the Board. I am not suggesting that that should have been the case; I am just arguing logically. That is why I find it difficult to understand this matter. Anyway, that is the position. Where do we go now? I do not blame the Liberal Party one iota for getting the absolute maximum mileage of political capital out of this matter that it can. If the Labor Party were in the same position, it would do the same. But surely there must be an end to it at some time, for several reasons: So that we in this Parliament can get on to something a little more important, such as the 50,000 nuclear bombs that exist in the world; such as the two million people in Australia living in poverty; such as the 100,000 kids who tonight will not have a bed in which to sleep; such as organised crime, which now involves $5 billion a year; such as 600,000 human beings in this country who are now unemployed. When shall we, as a parliament, get back to those trifling issues and off this all-consuming monster of the Bicentennial Authority?

SPEECH.PARA: I pay a tribute to the Melbourne Age, whose editorial this morning said this:
Dr Armstrong's settlement was excessively generous.
But then, dealing with the report of Dr Griffith, it went on to say:

The report paves the way for the authority to recover at least $240,000 paid as compensation. It would, we believe, be unwise to do so. For one thing, it would involve the authority in a long and probably costly and certainly distracting legal battle at the very time when it should be concentrating its efforts on pulling the bicentennial program together. For a second, there is an argument for saying that while Dr Armstrong got his windfall settlement partly as a result of Mr John Reid's over-generousness and partly as a result of the Prime Minister's inattention to detail, he got it legally, and he left on the basis of that agreed settlement.

To seek to undo the settlement now would not be a proper way for the Government to behave. True, it might help to remove some of Mr Hawke's undoubted embarrassment. But it would be unfair to Dr Armstrong. It would also be unfair to the authority itself, particularly now that Mr Reid has resigned and a new chairman has still to be appointed.

I should have thought that that was a very wise comment. I plead with the Opposition, I plead with Mr John Howard, and I plead with Mr Robert Hawke, the Prime Minister, to get together and to come to some bipartisan view on this matter, to say: `Okay, the lemon has been squeezed dry. Let us ask Dr Armstrong for so much back, or let us call it a day and not engage in a lengthy process which could take two years through the courts to reach finality'.

What would happen in the meantime? Would we get a self-respecting top citizen of this country to accept the job as Chairman of the Authority while he has to make a decision as to whether he demands $300,000 back from Dr David Armstrong? Not one self-respecting top citizen would touch the bicentenary with a 40-foot bargepole. What top executive would we get to fill the role of executive director when he is being invited into a minefield of the gargantuan proportions of this sort of thing? For God's sake, let us settle the thing now. If the Liberals think that they have another week or so more of mileage in this, quite rightly, bless them; let them go for it. But please have a light at the end of the tunnel where it can be said `Enough is enough', and where Mr Hawke and Mr Howard can get together to reach some settlement.

I come to the Authority itself. I have never been too impressed with birthday parties. I think that that is because I have had a few too many myself. In any event, I just question the wisdom of the decision-it was a decision of Mr Fraser and the Liberals-to spend $271m. Really, is it not possible to contemplate that we could be spending that money a little differently? Two hundred and seventy-one million dollars is a birthday party to end all birthday parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were going to have a water conservation plan for the Bicentennial but it has been scrapped.

—If that were a suggestion it would have my absolute and total support. I think that we ought to consider priorities. Instead of tall ships, dancing girls-if that is the suggestion-brass bands and whatever, why not make as a major priority an attempt to wipe out trachoma among Aborigines by the year 1988, or whatever? That is possible with this kind of money, $271m. What about doing more than paying lip-service to multiculturalism? Why not try to have by, say, 1995, every child in this country speaking two languages? Would not that be a great thing to celebrate as a birthday? Why not encourage every child at school in 1988 to have a project to say what kind of Australia they would like by the year 2000, what problems children face and see, and what solutions children see to the problems of this country? Is that not the kind of thing that we would want, and would that not be more appropriate? Should we not have, as Senator Sir John Carrick says, a water conservation plan, or something like that, rather than tall ships and races, and whatever?
—What about the road program?

—As I understand it that is already in place. I do not know whether it was Mr Fraser or Mr Hawke who thought of that, but it has my total commendation; it is fantastic. It is inevitable when something like this happens that there is a political scandal, or whatever, but surely soon there must be a light at the end of the tunnel. I plead with both the Labor Party and the Liberal Party not to let this matter go to litigation and to continue it for the next two years, because only the Bicentennial itself and the people of Australia would suffer from that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 23 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In the event of a major nuclear accident at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's Research Establishment at Lucas Heights, would legal liability for compensation rest at government, state or local level.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Atomic Energy Commission (AAEC), which operates the Lucas Heights Research Establishment, is of course a Commonwealth instrumentality. Peter Walsh in his answer to Question on Notice No. 411 (see Hansard, 6 December 1983 pages 3350-51). It is difficult to envisage circumstances where State or local government authorities could be liable for a major nuclear accident at the Research Establishment, although any question of liability, for example in the event of negligent performance of emergency procedures, would have to be determined in accordance with relevant legal principles, and would depend on the facts of the particular case.

(2) The emergency procedures which would apply to the protection of local residents in the event of an accident at Lucas Heights are set out in APTCARE (A Plan to Cope with Accidents at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission Research Establishment, Lucas Heights, New South Wales), a joint plan drawn up by the AAEC and New South Wales authorities. As Senator Walsh indicated in his answer to Question No. 588 (Hansard, 28 February 1984, page 87), copies of a document summarising APTCARE have been placed in the Parliamentary Library. This document may also be obtained from the AAEC by any interested member of the public.

APTCARE is currently in the final stages of being updated in consultation with State authorities, and a revised version of the APTCARE document is expected to be completed shortly. This document will be available to the public on request from the AAEC.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funding is provided to a `drop-in' centre for the unemployed called the `Rise and Shine Centre' at 754 Darling Street, Rozelle, New South Wales.
(2) What is the purpose of the funding referred to in (1) above.
(3) What training programs are provided by the centre referred to in (1) above.
(4) What external evaluation has been made of the success of the centre referred to in (1) above in achieving its aims.
(5) How regularly are reviews of such centres carried out.
(6) What control or supervision is exercised over the content, particularly the political content, of `courses' offered to unemployed persons attending such centres.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ``Rise 'n' Shine-Rozelle CYSS'' Local Management Committee (LMC) is receiving for the period 1 November 1984 to 31 October 1985 a standard Level 3 Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) Grant of $100,000. This grant is paid in quarterly instalments.

(2) The Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) is a Commonwealth Government labour force program. Its objective is to encourage communities to assist local unemployed young people to develop their capacity for obtaining and retaining employment, and also to become more self-reliant during periods of unemployment.

(3) Training and support programs currently offered by Rozelle CYSS include driving lessons, photography, hospitality industry training (bar person and waiting courses), electric guitar, drumming, radio workshop production, mechanics for women, Tai Chi, drawing, cookery and nutrition, and video production. In addition to these activities advice and assistance is provided to participants with respect to typing, job search, and job resume/applications.

(4) The New South Wales CYSS State Advisory Committee is responsible for monitoring the effective operation, management and development of CYSS in that State. The Committee assesses the performance of Rozelle CYSS and all other CYSS projects in New South Wales as part of a regular six monthly review program. Any particular difficulties which arise in relation to the operation of a project would be considered by the Committee as a matter of urgency and outside the normal review process.
Rozelle CYSS also conducts its own internal reviews and evaluations of its program, including consultations with local youth agencies and the Commonwealth Employment Service.

(5) Rozelle CYSS is visited monthly by a Field Officer of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations who ensures that the project is operating according to CYSS guidelines. The project is also required to submit two monthly financial reports and quarterly program activity reports to the Department.

(6) The primary responsibility for the conduct of the project, including the provision of appropriate courses, lies with the Local Management Committee (LMC). LMC members are elected annually at a duly advertised public meeting, except for the Manager of the local Office of the Comonwealth Employment Service (CES), who is an ex officio member of any CYSS LMC in the CES area.

The CYSS State Advisory Committee and the Field Officer are available to provide advice and support to CYSS projects experiencing temporary difficulties. In cases where such advice is not heeded and a project is in breach of the CYSS guidelines payment of its quarterly grant instalments can be suspended at any time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 May 1985 (Hansard page 1878), Senator Boswell asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister to recent taxation rulings 2121 and, the latest one, 2129, which have the effect of redefining salaries and wages, forcing many small business people who are genuine sub-contractors, consultants, share fishermen and share farmers into the pay as you earn taxation system. Does the Minister agree that this decision has resulted in small business people losing their independence and working capital, has created a more rigid labour market and has increased costs in the building, computer and insurance industries, and now for share fishermen and share farmers? Does the Minister also agree that the PAYE method of taxation is inappropriate due to the seasonal and unpredictable income of many of the people affected by this decision? Will the Minister and his Department review these rulings in the light of the hardship being caused?
During the debate on the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill 1985, also on 14 May 1985 (Hansard page 1983), the senator claimed that Taxation Ruling 2129 specifically states:
Share fishermen are considered to be employees for the purpose of sub-section 221A of the Act.

Where evidence exists that a master and servant relationship does not exist tax instalments are still considered necessary in most instances because payments are considered to be wholly or principally for the labour of the person in terms of paragraph (a) of the definition of salary or wages.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is not accepted that Taxation Rulings IT 2121 and IT 2129 have the effect of forcing many small business people who are genuine sub-contractors, consultants, share fishermen or share farmers into the PAYE taxation system. The Government does not agree with the contention that the rulings will result in small business people losing their independence and working capital or that the rulings will create a more rigid labour market or increase costs in those industries mentioned.

Where the deduction of tax instalments at standard rates is inappropriate because of special circumstances that apply to an employee or class of employees the income tax law authorises the Commissioner of Taxation to vary the rate of deduction so as to meet the special circumstances of that employee or class of employees. Consequently, the Government does not accept that the rulings will lead to hardship.

The honourable senator has, unfortunately, failed to quote Taxation Ruling IT 2129 in its proper context. The ruling deals with the question of whether certain payments to individuals are payments of `salary or wages' for the purpose of the PAYE provisions of the income tax law. In relation to share fishermen, the ruling states that where, amongst other things, work is performed under the direction and control of the owner and/or operator of a fishing vessel, it is considered that crew members (including the skipper) paid on a share of proceeds or share of catch basis are neither carrying on business in common nor in receipt of income jointly. The ruling is directed at employees as such, and individuals who are virtually in the same position as employees, attempting to circumvent the PAYE provisions by claiming, contrary to fact, to be carrying on a business. The ruling is not directed at fishermen genuinely carrying on a business of ``fishing operations'' within the meaning of the income tax law.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 September 1985 (Hansard page 502) Senator Durack asked me, as Minister representing the Attorney-General, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Acting Attorney-General if he is still the Acting Attorney-General otherwise the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to a report in a newspaper headed `18 tappers get Bowen's blessing'. That puts it more succinctly than I may be able to do. It refers to the fact that the Attorney-General has granted indemnities to at least 18 present and former members of the New South Wales Police Force who may give evidence to the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking which is investigating the New South Wales police tapes. How many indemnities have been recommended by the Royal Commissioner to date? How many have been approved by the Attorney-General? Does he still have under consideration further indemnities in this matter? Has the New South Wales Attorney-General taken similar action to indemnify these witnesses from prosecution under State law?
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is not correct to state that indemnities have been given to present and former members of the New South Wales Police Force who may give evidence to the Royal Commision. It is true that the Attorney-General has given indemnities to a number of such persons who have given evidence to the Royal Commission.

The indemnities granted were recommended to the Attorney-General by the Royal Commissioner pursuant to his Letters-Patent and in accordance with procedures announced by Mr Justice Stewart at a public hearing on 24 May 1985.

On that date His Honour stated, inter alia, ``The terms of reference refer to the publication of a notice requiring persons desiring indemnities to come forward. On Saturday, 1 June 1985 a notice will be published in various newspapers inviting persons to notify the commission in writing of their intention to appear before the commission and to give evidence. Such persons will be invited to furnish written statements of their evidence as soon as possible. Except in special circumstances, only persons giving such notice within 28 days of the commission's notice will be considered for the recommendation of the granting of indemnities against prosecution or the giving of undertakings by the New South Wales Police Commissioner.

Generally speaking, all persons making statements will be called to give oral evidence to the commission. Any person making a statement who expresses a wish at that time to receive an indemnity or undertaking will be advised prior to his or her appearance before the commission whether or not I am prepared, on the basis of the contents of the statement, which may be at that time unsigned, to recommend the grant of any such indemnity or the giving of any such undertaking, should the statement be signed at the time the person appears before the commission and should the other conditions specified in the letters patent be fulfilled.

Persons tentatively offered indemnities or undertakings will be called to give evidence. Such evidence will include, but will not be limited to, the adoption of the contents of the statement earlier provided. I shall decide what my recommendation will be during the course of the witness' evidence and make it known at that time. I have been advised by the Attorneys-General for the Commonwealth and the State of New South Wales and by the New South Wales Police Commissioner that they will act upon my recommendations.''

The Commission hearings, and hence His Honour's indication to witnesses as to whether he is or is not prepared to recommend indemnities, are in camera and are the subject of confidentiality orders pursuant to the Royal Commissions Act.

Accordingly, I believe it is inappropriate to indicate the number of indemnities that have been granted or recommended. That question will, no doubt, be dealt with in the Report of the Royal Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 23 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Since 1 January 1983 how many phone operators have been recruited by Telecom:

(b) for fixed terms of 3 months or less, and
(c) for fixed terms of more than 3 months.
(2) In each 6 month period since 1 January 1983, what proportion of staff whose fixed-term contract ended in that period were then recruited either permanently or for another fixed term.

(3) In each 6 month period since 1 January 1983, how many phone operators have been replaced after contracting Repetitive Strain Injury (RSI) and what steps have been taken to minimise the incidence of RSI when new equipment has been introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since 1 January 1983 the recruitment levels for Manual Assistance staff have been as follows:
(a) Staff permanently appointed-approximately 1270.

(b) and (c) It is not possible to ascertain the length of time of fixed terms of employment without a detailed examination of the individual records of all Manual Assistance staff. The employment is however approved in accordance with strict guidelines which focus on workload needs and vacancies which are not likely to be of a continuing nature. Fixed terms of employment of Manual Assistance staff since 1 January 1983 have totalled approximately 1200. A number of these are new employees and the remainder are existing fixed term staff whose initial periods of employment have been extended because the workload requirements have continued longer than initially expected or, who have re-engaged into other temporary vacancies which have arisen.

(2) Approximately 60-70 per cent of fixed term staff are either offered permanent appointment because a suitable vacancy has arisen or another fixed term contract because the workload requirement has extended longer than initially expected or another temporary vacancy has arisen.

(3) Telecom has a policy whereby staff reporting at least one week of time lost with RSI are immediately placed on the `inoperative staff list' which enables fixed term staff to be employed as replacements. This remains the situation until either the injured person returns to full time work or otherwise ceases.
The number of reported RSI cases in the Manual Assistance area, and therefore the number of staff replaced, are as follows:
January-June 1983-111
July-December 1983-183
January-June 1984-299
July-December 1984-801
January-June 1985-588

With regard to reducing the incidence of RSI in the Manual Assistance area, a joint Telecom-Australian Telephone and Phonogram Officers Association Task Force has recently completed an examination and has made recommendations on this matter. Action is about to commence on these recommendations and this along with a number of prevailing initiatives is expected to contribute to the reduction of RSI. Some examples are as follows:
The introduction of RSI education sessions for keyboard staff.
The preparation and introduction of comprehensive guidelines covering the implementation and use of screen based keyboard equipment.
The consideration of organisational strategies to introduce improved job design or job enlargement for keyboard staff.
The introduction of appropriately designed equipment and improved working environments and the ongoing consideration of improvements in these areas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 8 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the current effective rate of protection for the steel industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Steel Industry Plan, which commenced on 1 January 1984, the Commonwealth provides direct assistance to the steel industry through both tariffs and bounties.

It is difficult to measure the effective level of assistance provided by the bounties as they cover less than 50 per cent of the industry's output and operate on a sliding scale which provides for a phasing out of bounty payments as output increases. In any year the amount of bounty payment depends on the health of the industry.

Bounty payments for 1984-85 were $53.6m (about 75 per cent of the total available bounty). Based on an estimate for bounty payments in 1984-85 of $54.8m on the Industries Assistance Commission has indicated that the level of effective assistance provided by bounties and tariffs in 1984-85 would be of the order of 19 per cent (compared with 16 per cent in 1981-82).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 8 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the effective rate of protection for the shipbuilding industry as a result of the Government's policy decision in 1984.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The most recent estimates of effective rates of protection published by the Industries Assistance Commission for manufacturing (including shipbuilding-Australian Standard Industrial Classification number 3241) are for 1981/82.stimates for 1982/83 are currently being finalised and should be available shortly.

The IAC has advised that the impact on the average effective rate of assistance afforded the shipbuilding industry (ASIC number 3241) of the Government's policy decision announced on 11 October 1984, is expected to be relatively small. As a guide only, if the effect of extending the bounty to exports was to increase expenditure in 1985/86 by the full $10m allowed by the legislation, then the level of effective assistance would increase from around 20 per cent to about 25 per cent in 1985/86.

If the assistance level was estimated for only those shipbuilding activities eligible for bounty payments, the rate of assistance for eligible vessels would obviously be unchanged, but a greater proportion of the overall industry output will receive the bounty.

The bounty rate in 1985/86 of 22.5 per cent of the construction costs of vessels (to be reduced to 20 per cent in 1986/87) corresponds to a nominal rate of assistance approximately 29 per cent. This yields an effective rate for bountiable vessels of around 40 per cent.
The effect of the removal of the 2 per cent duty on components used in the construction of ships eligible for bounty on the effective rate, for all practical purposes, is minimal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 20 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Commonwealth Laboratories (Ross Committee) criticise the Animal Breeding Section of the National Biological Standards Laboratory for having:
(a) a low standard of animals;
(b) excessive related staff resources;
(c) excessive production costs; and
(d) unsatisfactory standards regarding considerations for animal welfare,
(2) What steps have been taken by the Government to rectify each of the criticisms referred to in (1) above.
(3) Did the Ross Report also recommend a high priority for the reduction of animal usage in the National Biological Standards Laboratory.
(4) Has any such usage reduction referred to in (3) above taken place; if so, what are the relevant details; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) New accommodation for the breeding of disease-free specific pathogen free mice has been provided in the Brucella building. The Pharmacology laboratory and its animal house have been transferred to better premises. A second veterinary officer, whose main duties are related to the control of animal disease, has been recruited and is operating in a well equipped diagnostic laboratory.
These actions have led to a marked increase in animal quality.

When the Report was released, the Government commissioned independent reviews of its findings in relation to the proposed new NBSL building generally and to the Animal Breeding Section particularly. These reviews were carried out by Dr John Smith, Animal Welfare Officer of the Australian National University, and by Sir Gustav Nossal, Director of the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research.

Dr Smith examined the related areas of staff resources and production costs in considerable detail. He concluded that the staff requirements at that time were `acceptable and reasonable' and `would ensure that all animals are properly cared for at all times'.

Both Dr Smith and Sir Gustav Nossal commented specifically on standards of animal welfare. Dr Smith concluded `that the spirit of the NHMRC-CSIRO Code of Practice for the Care and Use of Experimental Animals in Australia is being observed by the NBSL', and Sir Gustav stated that `I feel it is important to record, however, that the dedication of Dr Brian Portas and his staff who look after animals in NBSL deserve high commendation'.

I should emphasise that NBSL has a fully functional Animal Experimentation Ethics Committee and that two veterinary officers, both specialists in laboratory animal science, are responsible for the care and health of the laboratory animals.
(3) Yes.

(4) This already had been given, and continues to have, high priority. The numbers of animals issued by the Animal Breeding Section have decreased by about 30% in the past 2 years. This decrease was largely due to the replacement of animal tests for the potency of insulins by physicochemical tests.

Other significant actions have been the development by NBSL of cell culture methods to replace animal tests for testing the toxicity of plastics such as urinary catheters which are to be inserted into the body, an internationally recognised initiative, and the introduction of cell culture and other in vitro methods to replace some of the animal tests previously performed on hormones and on bacterial and viral vaccines.

While further reductions in animal usage can be confidently expected in the next few years, it is highly unlikely that the need for some animal tests on the therapeutic products will entirely disappear.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 22 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the `onus of proof', under the provisions of the draft Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985, rest with the widow of a World War II Veteran to establish her claim where the Veteran dies after 30 October 1985 from a disability not already accepted as related to his war service or if he was not in receipt of a totally and permanently incapacitated war pension; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Clause 119 of the draft Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985 (VEB) deals with the standard of proof to be applied in determining claims and applications for Repatriation benefits. My answer to Senate Question No. 492 outlines the reasons why clause 119 does not place an onus on any claimant, including a widow of a Veteran, to prove a claim.

The significance under clause 119 of whether a Veteran died or dies 40 years or more after service is in what standard of proof is to be applied by the Repatriation Commission in deciding whether or not the Veteran's death was service-related. Where, for example, a Veteran served overseas in World War II and died 40 years or more after the end of the war, namely after 30 October 1985, the civil standard of proof is to be applied under the VEB in determining a claim for a war widow's pension. This requires reasonable satisfaction that there are sufficient grounds for granting the claim. By contrast, the standard of proof that applied before amendments made by the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Act 1985, in respect of the determination of all claims, was satisfaction beyond reasonable doubt.

Even in those cases where the civil standard of proof now applies, I would expect many war widows' claims to be successful. Where a Veteran dies from an accepted war-related disability, a war widow's pension will be payable. Where a TPI pensioner dies, his war widow will be entitled automatically to a war widow's pension.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 23 August 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Do the provisions of Section 19 of the draft Veterans' Entitlement Bill 1985 (which is proposed to replace Section 47 of the Repatriation Act 1920) place an evidentiary onus on Veterans to establish a `reasonable hypothesis' by producing material to place before the Repatriation Commission before an application can proceed to full consideration by the Commission; if so, does this effectively place the `onus of proof' on the applicant whereas in the legislation it repeals, this `onus' rested with the Commission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Clause 119 of the draft Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985, which has the same effect as the amendments made to section 47 of the Repatriation Act 1920 in June 1985, deals with the standard of proof to be applied in determining claims and applications for Repatriation benefits. Clause 119 requires that, before a claim can be granted, the material before the Commission must raise a reasonable hypothesis that there is a connection between the Veteran's incapacity or death and service. It does not place an onus on the Veteran or widow to establish such an hypothesis. To assist in resolving concerns that had been expressed on this issue I sought an independent opinion from a leading Sydney Queen's Counsel in relation to the amendment to section 47 of the Repatriation Act. His advice was:

``In my view, a reference to `onus' in this context is quite inappropriate. Section 28 (1) of the Act provides for the Secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs to cause an investigation to be made into the matters to which the claim or application relates. Further, it is the duty of the Commission to satisfy itself of all matters relevant to the determination of the claim (section 29). Thus, although the claimant initiates the claim, it is quite unnecessary for him to provide any evidence. The evidence may be ascertained by the Secretary or the Commission or it may be provided by the claimant. As a practical matter, of course, a wise claimant will place before the Department all information in his possession which may be of assistance to his claim, but it is quite misleading, in the context of an inquisitorial proceeding, to talk of an `onus' lying on any part''.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 11 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the current situation with regard to biological control of (a) Galvanised Burr; (b) Noogoora Burr; (c) Love Grass; (d) Spiny Emex; (e) Bathurst Burr; (f) Wild Radish and Mustard Weed; (g) St John's Wort; (h) Parthenium Weed; (i) Saffron Thistle; (j) Perennial Bindweed; (k) Blackberry; (l) Caltrops; (m) Heliotrope; (n) Khaki Weed; (o) Water Hyacinth; (p) Serrated Tussock; (q) Lantana; (r) Collabah; (s) Silver Leaf Nightshade; and (t) Thistles.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following details in response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Galvanised Burr-Because it is native to Australia, there is little prospect of biological control of this weed.

(b) Noogoora Burr-Attempts to control this weed in the past by biological means have not been successful. However, a rust fungus thought to have been accidentally introduced with certain sunflower accessions is currently having a significant effect on this weed in Queensland. Unfortunately, and because its accidental release prevented proper screening, this rust fungus does cause damage to certain sunflower varieties.
(c) Love Grass-No work is planned and the chances of successfully controlling this weed by biological agents is considered to be low.

(d) Spiny Emex-Agents to control this weed have been released in the past. However, the insects only completed their life cycle in an irrigated release site in the Loxton area in South Australia. Both CSIRO and the Victorian Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands are currently conducting research in South Africa in an attempt to locate other control agents.

(e) Bathurst Burr-Previous releases of control agents have been unsuccessful. The New South Wales Department of Agriculture is currently conducting research to develop a mycoherbicide (biological herbicide) to control this weed. It will be some time before the research is completed.
(f) Wild Radish and Mustard Weed-CSIRO is currently conducting an initial survey in Europe to find control agents for Wild Radish. No work is planned for Mustard Weed.

(g) St John's Wort-A beetle has been previously released by CSIRO which has been found to be successful in controlling this weed in all but shaded areas. CSIRO is currently conducting further research to locate other agents.

(h) Parthenium Weed-Queensland Department of Lands has released an insect which is successfully attacking this weed but it has yet to be demonstrated that biological control alone will prove effective.
(i) Saffron Thistle-This weed is closely related to safflower which is an important oilseed crop. No work is planned to control this weed by biological means.
(j) Perennial Bindweed-No work is planned in Australia although the United States Department of Agriculture is currently doing research to find control agents.

(k) Blackberry-An illegal release of the rust fungus Phragmidium violaceum has been made by persons unknown and this is currently attacking most varieties of Blackberries in a number of regions. The Victorian Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands has conducted research into related rust fungi. Because of the possible conflict of interest among commercial berry growers and others who utilise Blackberries, it has been proposed that Blackberry be declared under the Biological Control Act 1984. Steps are being taken to initiate this action. If Blackberry is declared under the Act, the related rust fungi may also be released.
(l) Caltrops-No work is planned in Australia although the United States Department of Agriculture has done some work on this in the past.
(m) Common Heliotrope-The CSIRO is currently conducting research in France and in Australia to an agent to control this weed.
(n) Khaki Weed-No work is planned for this weed at present.
(o) Water Hyacinth-An insect released by CSIRO is successfully controlling this weed at present.
(p) Serrated Tussock-No work is planned for this weed at the moment.

(q) Lantana-This weed presents a problem because of its genetic diversity. A number of agents have been released in the past with only limited success. No work is currently being undertaken by CSIRO on this weed.

(r) Collabah-The Department of Primary Industry was unable to obtain information on a weed with this common name. If the reference is to either Eucalyptus coolabah or Coolibah grass (Thellungia advena) then there is little prospect of biological control as both are native species.

(s) Silver Leaf Nightshade-Steps are currently underway to have this weed controlled by biological means. Advertisements, in line with existing Standing Committee on Agriculture procedures, were placed in newspapers recently seeking public comments on the proposal that the weed be controlled by biological means. If no adverse comments are forthcoming it is probable that development of a means for biological control will proceed in the near future.
(t) Thistle-See comments for (s) above. The proposal for thistles concerns Nodding Thistle (Carduus nutans and C. thoermeri) and Slender Thistle (C. tenuiflorus and C. pycnocephalus).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have there been any government-to-government communications between Australia and the United States concerning renewal of the lease agreement for the Pine Gap joint defence facility.
(2) Has the Australian Government given any under-takings to the United States Government in regard to renewal of the lease agreement for the Pine Gap joint defence facility.

(3) Under the existing lease agreement or any other arrangement with the US Government, at what point is the Australian Government required to make a commitment for renewal of the lease agreement on the Pine Gap joint defence facility.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) The honourable senator's question is based on a misunderstanding about the nature of the agreement governing the establishment of the facility at Pine Gap. There is no ``lease agreement''. The agreement is published in the Australian `Agreement between the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia and the Government of the United States of America Relating to the Establishment of a Joint Defence Space Research Facility', Treaty Series (A.T.S.). It comprises two documents, the 9 December 1966, as extended and amended by an Exchange of Notes of 19 October 1977 (A.T.S. 1977 No. 24).

These documents are concerned with the terms and conditions of a partnership between the Australian and United States Governments involving the establishment and operation of the facility at Pine Gap. The joint nature of the responsibilities is reflected in Article 3 of the Agreement, which says:

``The facility shall be established, maintained and operated by the Cooperating agencies of the two Governments and information derived from the research programmes conducted at the facility shall be shared by the two Governments'.

The relevant current provision governing the currency of the Agreement is contained in the 1977 Exchange of Notes. It provides that the Agreement be extended for a period of ten years from 19 October 1977 and thereafter until terminated. After this extension has been in force for nine years ``either Government may at any time notify the other in writing that it desires to terminate the Agreement in which event the Agreement shall terminate one year after such notice has been given''.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many of the RAAF Mirage aircraft remain in operation.
(2) How many Mirage crashes were there during 1984 and to date in 1985.
(3) What were the costs of the extensive refurbishment programme which supposedly enables the Mirage aircraft to be operated safely beyond its original design airframe fatigue life.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are seventy-five Mirages remaining in active service (63 x 1110 fighters, 12 x 111D two seat trainers).

(2) During the period 1 January 1984 to 13 September 1985 there have been seven Mirage accidents involving eight aircraft. In these accidents, six aircraft were destroyed (two in one accident). The other two aircraft are considered repairable.

(3) The cost incurred for the structural elements of the Mirage refurbishment program is $30,997,318. This can be compared to a structural element project approval level of $32.753m in a total project approval of $71.794m (March 83 prices). Although some additional expenditure is expected, the final cost of the structural refurbishment will not alter significantly from this figure.
The structural refurbishment primarily involved the purchase of new wings and the refurbishment of existing wings.

The Mirage does not yet have a finite fatigue life, based on the safe life philosophy. In-service experience, testing and damage tolerance analysis have identified areas of the airframe prone to fatigue cracking and the hours at which this is likely to occur, with the RAAF's usage of the aircraft. The RAAF has adopted a safety-by-inspection philosophy for the lifing of the aircraft. A finite airframe fatigue life, within the boundaries of a test spectrum, is only now being determined, as a result of a tripartite test program.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 September 1985 (Hansard, pages 449-450) Senator Sanders asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned woodchip export licences and the Government's consideration of the environmental impact statement on Tasmanian woodchipping and associate forestry operations.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has advised that his statements in Tasmania during a two-day visit to inspect areas of concern in the operations of the woodchip industry reflected his view that licences would be renewed. That view is supported generally by the community in Tasmania. It is also consistent with the view held by the Forest Action Network, which represents conservation interests in Tasmania and is seeking to ensure that appropriate environmental protection measures are implemented by the forestry industry. The Minister made no comment on the volumes or the conditions which might be involved in renewal of licences.

The environmental impact statement (EIS) is being examined by the Government; the issues it raises have not been prejudged, but will be taken into account with other matters including the social and economic impact of any decision.

It is not the policy of the Government to close down industries, particularly in cases such as the forestry industry in Tasmania which is a significant and decentralised employer. The Government is concerned, nevertheless, to ensure, insofar as it has the power, that the industry operates in an environmentally sensitive manner.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 September 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will all the sections of the Crimes Amendment Act 1982 be proclaimed.
(2) Why have they not been already proclaimed.

(3) What is the nature of the financial obligation which would accrue to the Commonwealth in respect of payments involved in the imposition or work orders, as provided for by the Crimes Amendment Act 1982.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney- General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Consideration is being given to amending the Crimes Amendment Act 1982 to enable the unproclaimed provisions to be brought into force progressively as each jurisdiction enters into the arrangements the existence of which is a prerequisite to the operation of those provisions.

(2) Those provisions of the Crimes Amendment Act 1982 which have not yet been proclaimed require the making of arrangements by the Governor-General and each of the State Governors and the Administrator of the Northern Territory under which federal offenders may serve non-custodial sentences such as community service orders under the supervision of State or Territory officers. Difficulties have been raised by the States concerning certain financial and administrative aspects of the proposed arrangements.

(3) By virtue of section 120 of the Constitution the States are obliged to make provision for the punishment of persons convicted of offences against Commonwealth law. Accordingly, no direct financial obligation would accrue to the Commonwealth in respect of payments involved in the imposition of work orders, as provided for by the Crimes Amendment Act 1982. The Commonwealth Grants Commission would, of course, take into account the expenses incurred by the States in providing community service order schemes for federal offenders when determining the relative funding needs of the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 September 1985 (Hansard, pages 755-6) Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question without notice concerning the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme Review Authority's examination of claims for a separate category of assistance under the scheme for apples and pears.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

At the request of the Authority the Tasmanian Apple and Pear Growers Association has provided a submission in support of its claim for a separate commodity classification for apples and pears. Arrangements have been made for representatives of the Association to meet with members of the Authority on 15 October to discuss the submission and for the Authority to then determine the advice which it considers should be given to the Minister.

While no deadline has been set for completion of the Authority's report to the Minister on this matter, the Minister has asked for its early advice. A copy of the Authority's report to the Minister will be given to the Association.
